operation.description: Envelop artificial structures (walls, monotonous facades, infrastructural elements) in the background with layered vegetation screens to soften visual texture and reduce their dominance in the visual field

pathway.mechanism_description: Vegetation enveloping transforms harsh artificial textures into softer, natural visual patterns, reducing perceptual monotony and visual oppression. The layered green screening diminishes the negative aesthetic impact of artificial structures, thereby improving overall attractiveness by creating visual depth and naturalistic transitions from background to foreground elements

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of visible vegetation (trees and shrubs) at the block group scale to enhance streetscape green visibility and neighborhood environmental quality

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher green view index creates enhanced neighborhood amenity value and environmental appeal, attracting higher-income residents and increasing property desirability, thereby correlating with elevated median household income levels in the area

source.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

operation.description: Reduce visual complexity and texture variance in background building facades and streetscape elements to create more homogeneous, orderly visual environments with lower perceived entropy and chaos

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower visual complexity (measured by Shannon entropy index) in streetscapes is associated with higher median household income. Reducing textural heterogeneity, visual clutter, and disorderly elements creates more uniform and predictable visual environments that correlate with higher socioeconomic status neighborhoods. The negative relationship (DIR_NEG) between visual entropy and income suggests that socioeconomically advantaged areas exhibit more visually ordered streetscapes

source.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

operation.description: Redistribute vegetation resources to fill gaps in underserved areas of the neighborhood, reducing the Gini coefficient of greenery distribution and achieving more equitable green space access across all residential blocks.

pathway.mechanism_description: Equitable distribution of vegetation reduces environmental inequality, which is associated with social inequality. By filling vegetation gaps in deprived areas (infilling strategy), the intervention decreases neighborhood disparities that correlate with violent crime rates. More balanced green space access promotes social cohesion, increases informal surveillance through higher usage of outdoor spaces, and reduces territorial stigmatization that can foster criminal activity. The reduced Gini coefficient indicates fairer resource allocation, addressing underlying social determinants of crime.

source.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

operation.description: Accelerate restoration and establishment of street-level vegetation around newly constructed buildings to increase the size and coverage of foreground greenness visible from pedestrian viewpoints within the first years after construction completion.

pathway.mechanism_description: The negative direction (DIR_NEG) indicates that higher green view index correlates with lower apartment transaction prices in this context. Early restoration of street-level greenness may signal incomplete urban development or proximity to construction zones, potentially creating temporary negative perceptions that depress property values. The mechanism operates through visual perception channels where foreground vegetation density directly affects GVI measurements and subsequent buyer valuations during the post-construction transition period.

source.citation: An, S., Jang, H., Kim, H., Song, Y., & Ahn, K. (2023). Assessment of street-level greenness and its association with housing prices in a metropolitan area. Scientific Reports, 13(1).

operation.description: Strategically position trees within an 80-meter spatial grid to optimize visibility from pedestrian viewpoints. Tree placement should ensure consistent visual exposure throughout the streetscape, creating a rhythmic sequence of green elements visible from ground-level observer positions. The 80m interval corresponds to effective visual detection distance for physiological stress response.

pathway.mechanism_description: Tree visibility within the foreground visual field (≤80m) triggers parasympathetic nervous system activation, reducing electrodermal activity as measured by Skin Conductance Level (SCL). The spatial positioning ensures continuous exposure to tree canopies, which promotes attention restoration and stress recovery through biophilic engagement. The negative correlation between Tree View Factor and SCL indicates that optimized tree positioning within the visible foreground effectively lowers physiological stress markers.

source.citation: Cai, M., Xiang, L., & Ng, E. (2023). How does the visual environment influence pedestrian physiological stress? Evidence from high-density cities using ambulatory technology and spatial machine learning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 96, 104695.

operation.description: Morphing the skyline configuration by creating concave building facades and manipulating urban morphology to increase sky view factor (SVF) at street level; operate within 300m spatial grid units to optimize visible sky dome proportion and enhance openness perception in urban canyons.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased SVF through building facade morphing enhances perceived spatial openness and sky exposure, reducing psychological stress and physiological arousal. Greater sky visibility improves environmental legibility and sense of prospect, leading to parasympathetic nervous system activation and decreased skin conductance levels (SCL), indicating reduced stress response and improved psychological restoration in urban environments.

source.citation: Cai, M., Xiang, L., & Ng, E. (2023). How does the visual environment influence pedestrian physiological stress? Evidence from high-density cities using ambulatory technology and spatial machine learning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 96, 104695.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation density by adding trees, shrubs, and vertical greenery along roadways and pedestrian corridors to enhance Green View Index (GVI) in densely built urban areas with high ambient temperatures.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street-level vegetation coverage increases GVI, providing shade canopy that blocks direct solar radiation, reduces surface heat absorption, and promotes evapotranspiration cooling. This multi-layered vegetative barrier intercepts shortwave radiation before it reaches ground surfaces and building facades, thereby lowering ambient air temperatures at pedestrian level through combined shading and evaporative cooling effects.

magnitude.value: 0.05 decrease in Temp per unit GVI increase

source.citation: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

operation.description: Modify the sky view configuration in street canyons by reducing canopy obstruction to maintain higher Sky View Factor (SVF) values, thereby preserving greater sky openness and direct atmospheric exposure at the pedestrian level

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher SVF increases radiative heat exchange between ground surfaces and the open sky, particularly enhancing nocturnal longwave radiation cooling. This expanded view of the sky vault facilitates more effective heat dissipation during nighttime hours, reducing minimum temperatures while allowing solar gain during daytime, thereby dampening the diurnal temperature range (reducing the difference between daily maximum and minimum temperatures)

source.citation: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

operation.description: Increase street-level tree canopy coverage in foreground viewing zones to elevate Green View Index (GVI) above the 30% threshold, with priority implementation in suburban and peri-urban districts where current GVI levels fall below optimal perception standards. Deploy strategic tree planting along roadways, pedestrian corridors, and public spaces to maximize visual green exposure in human eye-level panoramic views.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding foreground tree presence directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-view imagery, thereby raising GVI metrics. The study demonstrates a negative correlation between current GVI levels and aesthetic performance in Pearl River Delta Urban Agglomeration, indicating that areas below 30% GVI threshold exhibit suboptimal visual quality. Adding trees in foreground spatial tier maximizes their contribution to eye-level green visibility, as proximity amplifies their coverage in human visual fields and street-view assessments. This size-based intervention (increasing vegetative mass in viewer proximity) addresses the identified deficiency in urban greening perception.

source.citation: Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

operation.description: For areas with low Green View Index (GVI), implement multi-layer planting strategies combining trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants to create vertical green volume in the foreground space. Prioritize eye-level vegetation coverage (1.5-3m height) to maximize immediate visual impact, while ensuring diverse canopy layers that enhance the perception of green abundance within pedestrian view corridors.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing foreground vegetation size through multi-layer planting directly enhances GVI by expanding green pixels in human eye-level photography and street view images. The vertical stratification creates denser green mass within the critical viewing angle (±30° from horizontal), thereby elevating perceived greenness and improving aesthetic environmental satisfaction. Multi-layer configurations also increase visual complexity and color variation, which positively correlates with green perception quality metrics.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Mean Green Perception Level = 12.56% (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Chen, Y., Zhang, Q., Deng, Z., Fan, X., Xu, Z., Kang, X., Pan, K., & Guo, Z. (2022). Research on Green View Index of Urban Roads Based on Street View Image Recognition: A Case Study of Changsha Downtown Areas. Sustainability, 14(23), 16063.

operation.description: In old urban streets with narrow sidewalks and limited planting space, implement vertical greening systems using climbing plants on building facades, walls, and vertical structures to increase vegetation coverage without occupying ground-level pedestrian space.

pathway.mechanism_description: Vertical greening increases the Green View Index (GVI) by adding visible vegetation layers in the foreground viewing zone. Climbing plants create green facades that occupy the primary visual field of street-level observers, effectively expanding the proportion of greenery in the streetscape. This approach is particularly effective in space-constrained environments where horizontal expansion is impossible, as it transforms underutilized vertical surfaces into green infrastructure that directly contributes to visual greenery perception and regional greenery assessment.

magnitude.value: descriptive: GVI higher in new urban areas compared to old urban areas (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Chen, Y., Zhang, Q., Deng, Z., Fan, X., Xu, Z., Kang, X., Pan, K., & Guo, Z. (2022). Research on Green View Index of Urban Roads Based on Street View Image Recognition: A Case Study of Changsha Downtown Areas. Sustainability, 14(23), 16063.

operation.description: Increase tree canopy coverage (size) in urban streetscapes through strategic planting of additional trees to expand the vertical and horizontal extent of green canopy in the middleground visual layer.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced tree canopy coverage increases the visual prominence and attractiveness of urban nature, creating photogenic scenes that draw visitors and social media engagement. Higher tree density generates clustered green spaces that serve as destination points, elevating implied urban nature vitality (IUNV) as measured through geotagged photo density on platforms like Flickr. The expanded canopy creates layered visual depth and shade amenities that encourage prolonged human interaction with streetscape environments.

source.citation: Chen, M., Cai, Y., Guo, S., Sun, R., Song, Y., & Shen, X. (2024). Evaluating implied urban nature vitality in San Francisco: An interdisciplinary approach combining census data, street view images, and social media analysis. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 95, 128289.

operation.description: Add trees strategically in foreground spaces to increase canopy coverage and reduce sky view factor (SVF) in pedestrian zones during hot seasons.

pathway.mechanism_description: Tree canopy addition increases the size and extent of overhead shade coverage, which directly reduces SVF by blocking visible sky hemisphere. Lower SVF diminishes shortwave and longwave radiation exposure to pedestrians, thereby reducing Physiological Equivalent Temperature (PET) and improving thermal comfort in urban environments.

source.citation: Chiang, Y.-C., Liu, H.-H., Li, D., & Ho, L.-C. (2023). Quantification through deep learning of sky view factor and greenery on urban streets during hot and cool seasons. Landscape and Urban Planning, 232, 104679.

operation.description: Replace evergreen trees with deciduous trees along sidewalks to optimize seasonal thermal performance through dynamic canopy characteristics that provide summer shading while allowing winter solar penetration

pathway.mechanism_description: Deciduous trees reduce Physiological Equivalent Temperature (PET) through seasonal leaf cycle: dense summer foliage increases Green View Index (GVI) and provides evaporative cooling and solar shading during hot periods, while winter leaf loss permits solar radiation to reach ground surfaces for passive warming, thereby balancing year-round thermal comfort needs in urban pedestrian environments

source.citation: Chiang, Y.-C., Liu, H.-H., Li, D., & Ho, L.-C. (2023). Quantification through deep learning of sky view factor and greenery on urban streets during hot and cool seasons. Landscape and Urban Planning, 232, 104679.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation coverage to achieve a minimum Green View Index (GVI) of 25% along pedestrian corridors, prioritizing tree canopy and vertical greenery within the immediate viewing zone (0-50m from observer).

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street greenery at GVI ≥25% improves pedestrian psychological comfort through multiple pathways: (1) increased visual connection with nature triggers restorative psychological responses, (2) green canopy provides thermal comfort through shading and evapotranspiration, (3) vegetation softens harsh urban geometry and reduces visual stress, and (4) creates perceived safety and place attachment. The 25% threshold represents a critical perceptual tipping point where street users report significant improvements in comfort and positive sentiment.

source.citation: Dong, R., Zhang, Y., & Zhao, J. (2018). How Green Are the Streets Within the Sixth Ring Road of Beijing? An Analysis Based on Tencent Street View Pictures and the Green View Index. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(7), 1367.

operation.description: For wide motorways (Type T1, >40m width), establish multi-layered central green belts featuring tall canopy trees (8-15m height) combined with dense understory shrubbery (2-4m height) to maximize vertical green volume and compensate for the negative correlation between road width and Green View Index observed in Beijing's urban streets.

pathway.mechanism_description: Wide roads reduce pedestrian-level GVI due to increased viewing distance from roadside vegetation. Central median planting with tall trees and dense shrubs creates additional green mass in the visual field, increasing the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level panoramic images. The multi-layered structure ensures vegetation visibility from multiple viewing angles, directly counteracting the dilution effect of road width on perceived greenness and improving aesthetic performance through enhanced visual green exposure.

source.citation: Dong, R., Zhang, Y., & Zhao, J. (2018). How Green Are the Streets Within the Sixth Ring Road of Beijing? An Analysis Based on Tencent Street View Pictures and the Green View Index. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(7), 1367.

operation.description: For major arterial roads (T4) and minor arterial roads (T5), strategically plant tall-canopy trees with large crown spreads to maximize vertical green coverage. Select tree species with broad, dense canopies that can reach heights of 8-15 meters at maturity. Ensure adequate spacing (6-10 meters) to allow full crown development while creating continuous overhead canopy coverage along street corridors.

pathway.mechanism_description: Taller trees with large crowns increase Green View Index (GVI) by occupying a greater proportion of the vertical field of view in street-level imagery. The expanded canopy size creates volumetric green presence that fills the visual frame from ground level, particularly effective on wider arterial roads where building setbacks and road widths create greater visual space. Large crown spreads enhance horizontal green coverage continuity, while height extends vertical green presence, collectively maximizing green pixels captured in panoramic street views.

source.citation: Dong, R., Zhang, Y., & Zhao, J. (2018). How Green Are the Streets Within the Sixth Ring Road of Beijing? An Analysis Based on Tencent Street View Pictures and the Green View Index. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(7), 1367.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of eye-level vegetation along secondary roads and bike-sharing corridors to enhance visual greenness perception from cyclists' viewpoint.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced eye-level greenness (measured by Green View Index) creates more pleasant and aesthetically appealing cycling environments, which increases users' willingness to choose dockless bike sharing as a transportation mode. The visual exposure to vegetation during trips provides psychological benefits and reduces perceived environmental stress, thereby promoting higher frequency of bike sharing usage.

source.citation: Gao, F., Li, S., Tan, Z., Zhang, X., Lai, Z., & Tan, Z. (2021). How Is Urban Greenness Spatially Associated with Dockless Bike Sharing Usage on Weekdays, Weekends, and Holidays? ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 10(4), 238.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage area of street-level vegetation (trees, shrubs, and ground cover plants) to elevate Green View Index (GVI) to optimal levels through systematic planting along sidewalks, building setbacks, and roadside buffers

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation coverage in the pedestrian viewshed directly increases GVI values captured through street view image segmentation. Enhanced visual greenness improves perceived spatial quality by creating naturalistic streetscapes, moderating microclimate, providing visual relief from hard surfaces, and fostering psychological restoration effects that collectively elevate street spatial quality scores

source.citation: Gao, L., Xiang, X., Chen, W., Nong, R., Zhang, Q., Chen, X., & Chen, Y. (2024). Research on Urban Street Spatial Quality Based on Street View Image Segmentation. Sustainability, 16(16), 7184.

operation.description: Add street furniture elements (benches, lighting fixtures, waste receptacles, bicycle racks) in the foreground zone along pedestrian pathways to enhance pedestrian convenience and usability

pathway.mechanism_description: Street furniture additions directly increase the Pedestrian Convenience Index (PCI) by providing essential amenities for rest, wayfinding, and basic needs. The strategic positioning of these elements in accessible foreground locations improves functional quality and perceived serviceability of street spaces, which are key components evaluated in street spatial quality assessments through street view image segmentation analysis

source.citation: Gao, L., Xiang, X., Chen, W., Nong, R., Zhang, Q., Chen, X., & Chen, Y. (2024). Research on Urban Street Spatial Quality Based on Street View Image Segmentation. Sustainability, 16(16), 7184.

operation.description: Optimize spatial composition to increase Sky View Factor (SVF) by maximizing visible sky area in the background layer through strategic arrangement of foreground and middleground elements, reducing visual obstruction of the sky dome.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher SVF creates visual openness and simplifies the visual field by reducing the number of competing visual elements in the upper field of view. Increased sky visibility provides a uniform, less complex background that reduces visual information density and cognitive processing demands. The negative correlation (DIR_NEG) between SVF and perceived scene complexity indicates that greater sky exposure directly decreases the visual complexity perception, thereby reducing mental stress and cognitive load associated with visually cluttered environments.

source.citation: Guan, F., Fang, Z., Wang, L., Zhang, X., Zhong, H., & Huang, H. (2022). Modelling people's perceived scene complexity of real-world environments using street-view panoramas and open geodata. ISPRS Journal of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing, 186, 315–331.

operation.description: Eradicate walls and fences separating residential blocks to transform gated communities into open-access neighborhoods, enabling visual and physical connectivity to green spaces across property boundaries

pathway.mechanism_description: Removing physical barriers alters the spatial position relationship between residents and green spaces, expanding the viewshed area and increasing green visibility exposure for previously blocked populations. This redistributes visual access to vegetation from privatized enclaves to the broader community, directly addressing spatial inequity in green visibility distribution by eliminating exclusionary infrastructure that creates visual dead zones

source.citation: Guo, X., Liu, C., Bi, S., & Tang, Y. (2025). Identification of Inequities in Green Visibility and Ways to Increase Greenery in Neighborhoods: A Case Study of Wuhan, China. Applied Sciences, 15(2), 742.

operation.description: Introduce evergreen tree species (Cinnamomum camphora, Osmanthus fragrans, Pinus spp.) to maintain consistent green coloration and visual continuity throughout winter months in street foreground planting zones.

pathway.mechanism_description: Evergreen foliage sustains year-round green visual index (GVI) values by preventing seasonal canopy loss, thereby maintaining consistent biophilic visual exposure that correlates with elevated self-reported relaxation scores through sustained nature contact and perceived environmental stability.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Relaxation score increased from mean=2.8 (low GVI) to mean=3.9 (high GVI) (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Hao, N., Li, X., Han, D., & Nie, W. (2024). Quantifying the Impact of Street Greening during Full-Leaf Seasons on Emotional Perception: Guidelines for Resident Well-Being. Forests, 15(1), 119.

operation.description: Selectively prune tree canopies in foreground areas where Tree-Sky View Factor (TSV) exceeds optimal thresholds or where dense foliage creates perception of enclosure and reduced safety, focusing on thinning techniques that maintain tree health while opening vertical sight lines to sky.

pathway.mechanism_description: Reducing excessive canopy density through pruning increases TSV ratio, enhancing visual connection to sky and improving perceived openness. Moderate TSV levels (avoiding both excessive closure and over-exposure) correlate with higher relaxation scores by balancing sense of enclosure with adequate openness, reducing claustrophobic sensations while maintaining shade benefits. Improved visibility and reduced shadowing also enhance perceived safety in street environments.

source.citation: Hao, N., Li, X., Han, D., & Nie, W. (2024). Quantifying the Impact of Street Greening during Full-Leaf Seasons on Emotional Perception: Guidelines for Resident Well-Being. Forests, 15(1), 119.

operation.description: Introduce evergreen plants like cinnamomum camphor, osmanthus, and pine for winter consistency.

pathway.mechanism_description: Maintaining GVI during winter months to sustain positive emotional impact.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Relaxation score increased from mean=2.8 (low GVI) to mean=3.9 (high GVI) (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Hao, N., Li, X., Han, D., & Nie, W. (2024). Quantifying the Impact of Street Greening during Full-Leaf Seasons on Emotional Perception: Guidelines for Resident Well-Being. Forests, 15(1), 119.

operation.description: Optimize the size and canopy coverage of existing green spaces with high GVI potential (such as parks and temples) by expanding tree canopy area, increasing vegetation density, and enhancing vertical layering to maximize visibility from street-level viewpoints in the middleground viewing distance.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing the size and density of vegetation in middleground parks directly enhances Green View Index (GVI) by expanding the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level panoramic images. Larger canopy coverage creates more continuous green surfaces visible from pedestrian perspectives, particularly at optimal viewing distances (30-100m), thereby improving aesthetic perception through increased visual contact with nature. This size optimization strategy is particularly effective for landscape objects already positioned within key viewsheds.

source.citation: Hu, A., Yabuki, N., Fukuda, T., Kaga, H., Takeda, S., & Matsuo, K. (2023). Harnessing multiple data sources and emerging technologies for comprehensive urban green space evaluation. Cities, 143, 104562.

operation.description: Improve the quality of existing green spaces with high potential GVI (like parks and temples) through regular maintenance and facility enhancement.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhancing existing structures to maintain high visual quality.

source.citation: Hu, A., Yabuki, N., Fukuda, T., Kaga, H., Takeda, S., & Matsuo, K. (2023). Harnessing multiple data sources and emerging technologies for comprehensive urban green space evaluation. Cities, 143, 104562.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation density (trees and shrubs) in central urban neighborhoods by adding multi-layered greenery to create denser foreground texture along pedestrian pathways and building facades, enhancing the Green View Index (GVI) at eye-level viewing angles.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation density at eye-level increases perceived safety by improving natural surveillance opportunities (prospect-refuge theory), creating defined territorial boundaries, increasing legitimate street activity through attractive green environments, and enhancing perceived maintenance and social order signals. Dense foreground vegetation serves as symbolic barriers that deter criminal behavior while maintaining visual permeability for legitimate users, thereby reducing fear of robbery, harassment, and break-ins.

source.citation: Jing, F., Liu, L., Zhou, S., Song, J., Wang, L., Zhou, H., Wang, Y., & Ma, R. (2021). Assessing the Impact of Street-View Greenery on Fear of Neighborhood Crime in Guangzhou, China. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 18(1), 311.

operation.description: Maintain and increase street-level vegetation visibility through regular care, pruning, cleaning, and health management to ensure continuous green coverage and prevent deterioration that signals environmental disorder

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher Green View Index (GVI) reduces perceived physical incivilities by creating visual cues of active maintenance and care. Well-maintained vegetation displaces visual exposure to disorder indicators (abandoned objects, trash, graffiti, damaged facilities), strengthening perceptions of territorial control and community investment, which mediates feelings of safety

source.citation: Jing, F., Liu, L., Zhou, S., Song, J., Wang, L., Zhou, H., Wang, Y., & Ma, R. (2021). Assessing the Impact of Street-View Greenery on Fear of Neighborhood Crime in Guangzhou, China. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 18(1), 311.

operation.description: Optimize the size and density of street-side vegetation to achieve a minimum Green View Index (GVI) of 25% along urban roads, ensuring vegetation occupies at least one-quarter of the visual field from pedestrian eye-level perspective. This involves calibrating canopy width, planting density, and vertical layering of trees and shrubs to meet the quantitative greening threshold while maintaining visual comfort.

pathway.mechanism_description: Achieving a GVI of ≥25% enhances aesthetic experience by creating a visually balanced streetscape where greenery provides sufficient natural visual relief without overwhelming the urban context. This threshold ensures adequate green coverage in the pedestrian's field of view, which has been empirically linked to improved perceived environmental quality, psychological comfort, and overall satisfaction with urban green space. The size optimization of vegetation elements directly increases the proportion of natural elements visible to street users, thereby elevating the aesthetic performance of the street environment.

source.citation: Jing, X., Li, Z., Chen, H., & Zhang, C. (2024). "Is What We See Always Real?" A Comparative Study of Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Urban Green Spaces: The Case of Shenzhen's Central District. Forests, 15(6), 983.

operation.description: Target a Green View Index of at least 25% for urban roads to ensure a comfortable level of greening.

pathway.mechanism_description: Ensuring minimum visible vegetation coverage.

source.citation: Jing, X., Li, Z., Chen, H., & Zhang, C. (2024). "Is What We See Always Real?" A Comparative Study of Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Urban Green Spaces: The Case of Shenzhen's Central District. Forests, 15(6), 983.

operation.description: Increase street tree canopy coverage and density in central urban districts (specifically Nakagyo Ward in Kyoto) through systematic addition of street trees along roadways to achieve GVI levels comparable to suburban areas (target: reducing the center-suburb GVI disparity identified through deep neural network analysis).

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding street trees in the central urban core directly increases visible greenery from street-level perspective, thereby elevating Green View Index (GVI) values. The expanded tree canopy coverage in the foreground and middleground of street views enhances the proportion of green pixels captured in streetscape imagery, which is quantified by deep learning-based semantic segmentation algorithms to compute GVI scores.

source.citation: Kameoka, T., Uchida, A., Sasaki, Y., & Ise, T. (2022). Assessing streetscape greenery with deep neural network using Google Street View. Breeding Science, 72(1), 107–114.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street-level vegetation in the foreground visual field, including roadside trees, planting strips, and green infrastructure elements along pedestrian pathways to enhance the Green View Index (GVI).

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher street-level vegetation visibility creates more aesthetically pleasing and thermally comfortable walking environments, which positively influences pedestrian route choice, walking frequency, and duration. The increased greenery provides visual interest, shade, and perceived naturalness that encourages active mobility behaviors.

source.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

operation.description: Add or increase street trees at eye-level (foreground) along cycling routes to maximize visual contact with green vegetation, prioritizing canopy trees that create visible greenness from cyclist perspective rather than overhead satellite-measurable coverage.

pathway.mechanism_description: Eye-level green view index (GVI) creates immediate visual engagement with nature during cycling, enhancing aesthetic pleasure and perceived environmental quality. Foreground vegetation provides proximate sensory stimulation that satellite-measured greenness (NDVI/canopy cover) fails to capture, directly influencing route preference and cycling motivation through improved visual experience and psychological comfort.

source.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and visible area of green vegetation in the foreground visual field through strategic planting to enhance Green View Index (GVI) in urban streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI creates a perception of natural surveillance and environmental care, which signals maintained and monitored spaces. The presence of visible greenery reduces visual obstruction anxiety while increasing aesthetic appeal and sense of territoriality, thereby enhancing perceived safety. Green vegetation also attracts more pedestrian activity, creating 'eyes on the street' that further improve safety perceptions.

source.citation: Kang, Y., Zhang, F., Gao, S., Lin, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). A review of urban physical environment sensing using street view imagery in public health studies. Annals of GIS, 26(3), 261–275.

operation.description: Reduce visual complexity of foreground vegetation by simplifying planting patterns, limiting species variety, and maintaining clear sightlines through selective thinning and pruning to achieve low-to-medium density arrangements that balance greenery provision with visual permeability.

pathway.mechanism_description: High visual complexity in vegetation creates visual barriers and concealment opportunities that reduce perceived safety by limiting surveillance capability and the prospect–refuge balance. By reducing excessive complexity through simplified textures and organized patterns, the intervention enhances visual penetration depth, improves detection of potential threats, and increases perceived control over the environment, thereby strengthening the sense of safety and comfort in urban green spaces.

source.citation: Kawshalya, L. W. G., Weerasinghe, U. G. D., & Chandrasekara, D. P. (2022). The impact of visual complexity on perceived safety and comfort of the users: A study on urban streetscape of Sri Lanka. PLOS ONE, 17(8), e0272074.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of eye-level vegetation along street corridors to enhance green visual interface within pedestrian viewsheds (typically 1.5-2m height range). This includes adding street trees with lower canopy branches, vertical greenery systems, planted buffers, and layered shrub compositions that maximize green visibility from walking perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher Green View Index (GVI) at eye-level creates visually appealing walking environments that increase pedestrian comfort and psychological restoration, thereby motivating longer duration and greater frequency of utilitarian walking trips (e.g., commuting, errands). The enhanced visual greenery acts as a positive environmental cue that reduces perceived effort and increases route attractiveness for functional walking activities.

source.citation: Ki, D., & Lee, S. (2021). Analyzing the effects of Green View Index of neighborhood streets on walking time using Google Street View and deep learning. Landscape and Urban Planning, 205, 103920.

operation.description: Increase street tree canopy coverage and density along utilitarian walking routes in low-income neighborhoods to enhance green view index. Focus on arterial roads, commercial corridors, and pedestrian pathways connecting residential areas to transit stations, schools, and shopping districts.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher green visibility (GVI) along utilitarian walking routes creates more pleasant pedestrian environments that reduce perceived walking effort and heat stress, thereby encouraging residents to choose walking over motorized transportation for daily functional trips. The negative direction indicates that increased GVI is associated with reduced utilitarian walking time, likely because improved route aesthetics makes walking more efficient and comfortable, potentially shifting trip patterns. Low-income populations show heightened sensitivity as they have fewer transportation alternatives and greater reliance on walking infrastructure quality.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Reduction in walking inequity; Increase in physical activity for low-income groups

source.citation: Ki, D., & Lee, S. (2021). Analyzing the effects of Green View Index of neighborhood streets on walking time using Google Street View and deep learning. Landscape and Urban Planning, 205, 103920.

operation.description: Install visible accessibility features including sidewalks with clear wayfinding, pedestrian-scale streetlights, benches at regular intervals, and curb cuts to enhance walkway infrastructure and visual permeability in the foreground layer

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced walkway visibility and accessibility features (IND_VAC) improve perceived safety (PRF_SAF) through increased legibility of circulation routes, better nighttime illumination reducing concealment opportunities, and passive surveillance from amenity users. The addition of structured pedestrian infrastructure creates territorial definition and signals maintained public space, thereby increasing TrueSkill Safety Scores through enhanced environmental cues of safety and social presence

source.citation: Larkin, A., Gu, X., Chen, L., & Hystad, P. (2021). Predicting perceptions of the built environment using GIS, satellite and street view image approaches. Landscape and Urban Planning, 216, 104257.

operation.description: Optimize street vegetation distribution to create coherent, clustered patterns rather than random or scattered configurations along roadways, emphasizing spatial continuity and visual grouping of green elements

pathway.mechanism_description: Clustered vegetation arrangement enhances visual coherence and spatial legibility, creating predictable rhythmic patterns that improve environmental readability. This structured green distribution establishes clear visual hierarchy and territorial definition, reducing spatial ambiguity and perceived risk. The coherent vegetation texture provides consistent visual cues for wayfinding and territorial demarcation, which enhances user confidence and perceived safety through improved spatial orientation and reduced concealment opportunities

source.citation: Larkin, A., Gu, X., Chen, L., & Hystad, P. (2021). Predicting perceptions of the built environment using GIS, satellite and street view image approaches. Landscape and Urban Planning, 216, 104257.

operation.description: Increase the proportion and coverage of visible vegetation (including trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants) in street-level foreground views to enhance Green View Index (GVI) values in urban streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced visual exposure to green vegetation in the foreground improves psychological restoration, reduces mental fatigue, and promotes emotional well-being through biophilic responses. Higher GVI correlates with lower stress levels, improved mood states, and enhanced overall mental health outcomes at the population level, as measured through psychometric assessments and health surveys.

source.citation: Lee, D.H. et al. (2024). A Review on Recent Deep Learning-Based Semantic Segmentation for Urban Greenness Measurement. Sensors, 24, 2245.

operation.description: Mitigate the 'wall effect' by applying vertical greening systems or artistic decorative elements to blank wall surfaces to transform monotonous vertical facades into visually enriched interfaces in the foreground viewing zone.

pathway.mechanism_description: Large blank walls create visual monotony and oppressive spatial enclosure that elevates perceived depression scores. By overlaying green vegetation or artistic textures onto wall surfaces, the intervention breaks up the uniform plane, introduces natural or cultural visual interest, softens hard architectural edges, and provides positive visual stimulation that reduces psychological distress and depressive feelings in urban environments.

source.citation: Lei, Y., Zhou, H., Xue, L., Yuan, L., Liu, Y., Wang, M., & Wang, C. (2024). Evaluating and Comparing Human Perceptions of Streets in Two Megacities by Integrating Street-View Images, Deep Learning, and Space Syntax. Buildings, 14(6), 1847.

operation.description: Envelop underside surfaces of elevated viaduct structures with green infrastructure elements (vertical gardens, hanging vegetation, modular planting systems) to visually soften and naturalize the ceiling texture, transforming oppressive overhead concrete into biophilic overhead canopy within pocket parks beneath transportation infrastructure.

pathway.mechanism_description: Green enveloping of viaduct ceilings reduces psychological depression by: (1) masking oppressive gray concrete surfaces that induce negative affect through environmental monotony and institutional aesthetics; (2) introducing natural textures and organic patterns that provide visual interest and cognitive restoration; (3) creating perceived enclosure by vegetated 'sky' that enhances sense of intimate refuge rather than infrastructural exposure; (4) signaling environmental care and place identity that counters perceptions of neglected residual spaces. The textural transformation from hard industrial surfaces to soft living materials directly counteracts depressing environmental cues.

source.citation: Lei, Y., Zhou, H., Xue, L., Yuan, L., Liu, Y., Wang, M., & Wang, C. (2024). Evaluating and Comparing Human Perceptions of Streets in Two Megacities by Integrating Street-View Images, Deep Learning, and Space Syntax. Buildings, 14(6), 1847.

operation.description: Quantify the visible green vegetation coverage at street level using modified Green View Index (GVI) methodology with enhanced sampling: capture 18 panoramic images per location (6 horizontal headings at 60° intervals × 3 vertical angles: 0°, 30°, 60°) to measure the proportion of green pixels in the pedestrian visual field

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher visible greenery coverage in the foreground street environment enhances perceived safety through multiple pathways: (1) increased visual softness and naturalness reduce perceived threat, (2) well-maintained vegetation signals community care and informal surveillance, (3) green elements provide psychological restorative effects reducing anxiety, and (4) vegetation presence indicates active use and maintenance of public spaces, collectively improving crowdsourced safety perception scores

predicted_effect.indicator_change: More accurate GVI (typically lower than old GVI unless canopy is dense overhead)

source.citation: Li, X., Zhang, C., & Li, W. (2015). Does the Visibility of Greenery Increase Perceived Safety in Urban Areas? Evidence from the Place Pulse 1.0 Dataset. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 4(3), 1166–1183.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and canopy size of street trees and foreground vegetation along roadways to enhance the proportion of visible greenery in street-level views, specifically targeting the eye-level visual field captured from pedestrian and vehicular perspectives.

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding street trees and vegetation in the foreground tier directly increases the Green View Index (GVI) by expanding the pixel proportion of green elements within Google Street View imagery. Street-level trees positioned in close proximity to viewing angles occupy larger portions of the visual field, thereby maximizing their contribution to GVI calculations through computational image analysis that quantifies green pixel density.

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

operation.description: Increase tree canopy coverage in street canyons through strategic planting of trees to reduce sky view factor and enhance spatial enclosure

pathway.mechanism_description: Tree canopies occupy overhead space within the street canyon, physically obstructing the visible sky area when viewed from street level. Larger canopy size and increased tree density progressively reduce the Sky View Factor by blocking sightlines to the sky hemisphere, thereby modulating the degree of openness and creating shaded microenvironments along streetscapes

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2017). Mapping Urban Landscapes Along Streets Using Google Street View. Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, 341–356.

operation.description: Implement strategic shrub planting in industrial zones to increase shrub coverage area. Focus on establishing continuous shrub layers that can provide effective ground shading and evapotranspiration surfaces, particularly in areas with high heat emission sources such as parking lots, equipment yards, and buffer zones between industrial facilities.

pathway.mechanism_description: Shrubs reduce land surface temperature through multiple mechanisms: (1) canopy shading reduces direct solar radiation absorption by built surfaces; (2) evapotranspiration from shrub foliage converts sensible heat to latent heat, cooling ambient air; (3) shrub layers create vertical thermal barriers that mitigate heat radiation from industrial surfaces; (4) dense shrub coverage increases surface albedo compared to bare ground or impervious surfaces. In industrial contexts, shrubs demonstrate significant cooling performance despite lower height compared to trees, as they effectively cover larger ground areas and provide continuous thermal regulation at the micro-scale.

source.citation: Li, B., Xing, H., Cao, D., Yang, G., & Zhang, H. (2022). Exploring the Effects of Roadside Vegetation on the Urban Thermal Environment Using Street View Images. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 19(3), 1272.

operation.description: Increase the proportion and coverage of vegetation elements within the middleground visual field by adding green infrastructure, street trees, green walls, or landscape plantings to enhance visible greenery from eye-level perspectives in urban streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher Green View Index (GVI) at middleground distances provides visual access to natural elements that trigger psychological restoration processes through attention restoration theory mechanisms. Increased vegetation visibility reduces mental fatigue, promotes involuntary attention, and facilitates stress recovery by offering softly fascinating natural stimuli that allow directed attention to rest, thereby enhancing perceived restorativeness as measured by PRS.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Introduce visible water features (e.g., fountains, ponds, streams) in the middleground viewing zone to create visually accessible blue space elements that enhance environmental legibility and spatial coherence. Position water elements at 10-30 meters from primary viewing points to optimize perceptual engagement while maintaining adequate visual detail and auditory accessibility.

pathway.mechanism_description: Visible water features facilitate restorative experiences through multiple pathways: (1) providing 'soft fascination' that enables attention restoration theory (ART) mechanisms—water's dynamic yet predictable movement captures involuntary attention without mental fatigue; (2) enhancing perceived naturalness and environmental preference, which triggers stress reduction via psycho-evolutionary theory (PET) pathways; (3) creating multi-sensory engagement through visual and auditory stimulation that promotes mindfulness and present-moment awareness; (4) serving as focal points for contemplation that support reflection and emotional regulation. The middleground placement optimizes these effects by balancing visual prominence with spatial comfort, allowing sustained observation without overwhelming proximity.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation coverage to achieve >50% Green View Index (GVI) through strategic placement of trees, shrubs, and vertical greening elements within pedestrian viewshed at eye level (1.6m height). Prioritize canopy trees along sidewalks and planting strips to maximize visual greenness in foreground perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced visual exposure to greenery at street level reduces psychological stress and encourages active transportation (walking/cycling), which collectively lower cardiovascular disease risk factors including hypertension, sedentary behavior, and chronic inflammation. The 50% GVI threshold represents a critical dose-response point where cumulative visual contact with nature during daily mobility patterns produces measurable reductions in ischemic heart disease incidence through stress mitigation pathways and increased physical activity.

source.citation: Li, X., Liu, Q., Liu, X., & Ren, Y. (2025). Greener is healthier: Unraveling the distinction of health impacts of urban green indicators in Wuhan, China. Sustainable Cities and Society, 125, 106318.

operation.description: Optimize street canyon geometry by adjusting building height-to-width ratios to maximize sky view factor (SVF), ensuring adequate visual openness and reducing spatial enclosure in urban corridors

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher SVF values increase visible sky proportion from ground level, enhancing natural light exposure, reducing perceived spatial oppression, and promoting psychological restoration. Increased daylight penetration and improved air circulation may reduce cardiovascular stress responses, thereby lowering ischemic heart disease (IHD) incidence through enhanced environmental quality and restorative urban experiences

source.citation: Li, X., Liu, Q., Liu, X., & Ren, Y. (2025). Greener is healthier: Unraveling the distinction of health impacts of urban green indicators in Wuhan, China. Sustainable Cities and Society, 125, 106318.

operation.description: Increase the visible area and density of trees in the foreground viewing zone to enhance Green View Index (GVI), particularly in streetscapes with low architectural quality. Priority should be given to street-level planting that maximizes canopy coverage within the visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI increases the proportion of natural green elements in the visual field, compensating for poor architectural aesthetics through biophilic attraction. The relationship between GVI and general landscape score is non-linear (DIR_NLN), suggesting threshold effects where modest increases in visible greenery yield disproportionate perceptual benefits, especially in visually degraded environments. Trees in the foreground tier provide immediate visual screening and aesthetic enhancement.

source.citation: Cheng, L., Chu, S., Zong, W., Li, S., Wu, J., & Li, M. (2017). Use of Tencent Street View Imagery for Visual Perception of Streets. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 6(9), 265.

operation.description: Increase foreground tree coverage and density to elevate Green View Index (GVI) levels, transforming low-vegetation urban corridors ('Urban Jungle' typology) into greener streetscapes ('Flanked by Nature' or 'Boulevard' typologies) through strategic planting of street trees along pedestrian sight lines.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced foreground tree presence directly increases the proportion of vegetation visible in the visual field, which positively correlates with aesthetic perception scores. The study reveals spatio-temporal evolution patterns showing that higher GVI values (achieved through increased tree coverage) significantly improve visual beauty ratings in street-level environments. Trees in the foreground tier have maximum visual impact as they dominate the immediate viewing cone of pedestrians.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Increase in Beauty and Safety scores

source.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

operation.description: Preserve existing mature street trees and their canopy coverage during road maintenance, construction, or urban renewal activities through protective barriers, root protection zones, and construction scheduling that avoids peak growing seasons.

pathway.mechanism_description: Preservation of mature trees maintains established Green View Index (GVI) levels in the visual field, preventing perceptual decline caused by tree removal. Mature trees contribute significantly to foreground vegetation visibility in street-level imagery, and their loss directly reduces GVI values and triggers negative cluster shifts in perceptual assessments. Protection measures ensure continuity of the existing visual greenery infrastructure.

source.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

operation.description: Increase street tree canopy coverage and density in residential neighborhoods to enhance Green View Index (GVI) at eye-level perspective, targeting visual field occupation of vegetation within pedestrian viewsheds along primary walking routes and residential frontages.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced GVI through increased tree canopy presence creates restorative visual environments that reduce psychological stress and negative emotional states. The mechanism operates through attention restoration theory: natural green elements in the visual field reduce rumination, lower cortical arousal, and facilitate emotional regulation, thereby decreasing negative affect as measured by PANAS scale (direction: negative correlation).

magnitude.value: 10.3 decrease in Neg Affect per unit GVI (coeff)

source.citation: Liu, Y., Xiao, T., Liu, Y., Yao, Y., & Wang, R. (2021). Natural outdoor environments and subjective well-being in Guangzhou, China: Comparing different measures of access. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 59, 127027.

operation.description: Remove visual obstructions (vegetation, structures, or barriers) between streets and water bodies to increase blue visibility index (BVI) from pedestrian viewpoints, creating clear sightlines to blue spaces in the background layer.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced visual access to water features increases blue visibility index, which positively correlates with life satisfaction (SWLS scores 5-35) through psychological restoration, stress reduction, and improved environmental quality perception. The presence of visible water in urban landscapes provides calming visual stimuli and strengthens human-nature connection.

magnitude.value: High coeff magnitude due to low base BVI

source.citation: Liu, Y., Xiao, T., Liu, Y., Yao, Y., & Wang, R. (2021). Natural outdoor environments and subjective well-being in Guangzhou, China: Comparing different measures of access. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 59, 127027.

operation.description: Select tree species with low fractal dimension (simple leaf shapes, larger leaf surfaces) for street planting in areas with low green exposure ratio. Priority should be given to broadleaf species with smooth margins and reduced complexity in canopy texture to maximize cooling performance.

pathway.mechanism_description: Trees with low fractal dimension possess larger, less complex leaf structures that create denser, more continuous canopy coverage. This morphological characteristic enhances shading efficiency and increases the leaf area available for evapotranspiration, thereby producing stronger cooling effects on land surface temperature. The nonlinear relationship indicates that in streets with limited green space, selecting low-FD species amplifies the cooling benefit per unit of vegetation, compensating for lower overall green exposure.

source.citation: Liu, Z., Ma, X., Hu, L., Liu, Y., Lu, S., Chen, H., & Tan, Z. (2022). Nonlinear Cooling Effect of Street Green Space Morphology: Evidence from a Gradient Boosting Decision Tree and Explainable Machine Learning Approach. Land, 11(12), 2220.

operation.description: Select vegetation species with high Color Saturation Index (CSI), characterized by light-colored or vivid leaves, for street green space planting. Prioritize species displaying bright green, yellow-green, or variegated foliage with enhanced color intensity rather than dark or dull leaf colors.

pathway.mechanism_description: High CSI vegetation exhibits greater reflectance in the visible spectrum, reducing solar radiation absorption and subsequent heat accumulation. The lighter and more saturated leaf colors increase albedo effect, thereby lowering surface temperatures through enhanced reflection of shortwave radiation. This color-mediated cooling mechanism operates through reduced thermal conversion at the leaf surface, creating a nonlinear cooling effect on Land Surface Temperature in street environments.

source.citation: Liu, Z., Ma, X., Hu, L., Liu, Y., Lu, S., Chen, H., & Tan, Z. (2022). Nonlinear Cooling Effect of Street Green Space Morphology: Evidence from a Gradient Boosting Decision Tree and Explainable Machine Learning Approach. Land, 11(12), 2220.

operation.description: Increase texture richness and visual complexity on building facades through architectural detailing, ornamentation, and material variation to enhance visual distinctiveness of middleground elements in public open spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced facade texture and architectural details provide stronger visual cues and memorable landmarks that improve spatial legibility. Deep learning-based analysis demonstrates that textured building surfaces with ornamental features create distinctive visual anchors that help users form cognitive maps and navigate spaces more effectively, contributing significantly to high legibility scores by increasing the recognizability and differentiation of urban environments

source.citation: Liu, W., Hu, X., Song, Z., & Yuan, X. (2023). Identifying the integrated visual characteristics of greenway landscape: A focus on human perception. Sustainable Cities and Society, 99, 104937.

operation.description: Enhance architectural ornamentation and facade details on buildings to improve visual richness and distinguishability.

pathway.mechanism_description: Complex architectural details provide visual cues that aid in memory and navigation.

source.citation: Liu, W., Hu, X., Song, Z., & Yuan, X. (2023). Identifying the integrated visual characteristics of greenway landscape: A focus on human perception. Sustainable Cities and Society, 99, 104937.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and spatial coverage of street-level vegetation within pedestrian viewsheds to enhance Green View Index (GVI) along recreational corridors and public outdoor spaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street greenery at eye-level increases visual exposure to natural elements, creating more attractive and inviting outdoor environments. Higher GVI values improve environmental aesthetics and thermal comfort, which psychologically motivates residents to engage in recreational walking, jogging, and outdoor leisure activities. The visible presence of vegetation acts as a positive environmental cue that reinforces pro-health behaviors.

source.citation: Long, Y., & Ye, Y. (2019). Measuring human-scale urban form and its performance. Landscape and Urban Planning, 191, 103612.

operation.description: Morph building envelope geometry by adjusting height-to-width ratios (H/W aspect ratio) of street canyons to optimize sky view factor and control solar access patterns throughout diurnal and seasonal cycles

pathway.mechanism_description: Modifying building height relative to street width alters the sky view factor (SVF), which directly governs the amount of visible sky hemisphere from street level. Higher aspect ratios (taller buildings, narrower streets) reduce SVF and create deeper shadows with limited solar penetration, while lower aspect ratios increase SVF allowing greater solar exposure. This geometric transformation controls the spatiotemporal distribution of direct and diffuse solar radiation within the street canyon microclimate

source.citation: Long, Y., & Ye, Y. (2019). Measuring human-scale urban form and its performance. Landscape and Urban Planning, 191, 103612.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and density of vegetation elements at eye-level (1.5-2m height) along street corridors to enhance Green View Index (GVI), focusing on foreground visual field through strategic placement of street trees, shrubs, and vertical greenery systems within pedestrian sightlines.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced eye-level greenness creates visually appealing streetscapes that positively influence walking behavior through multiple pathways: (1) increased aesthetic quality and visual interest reduce perceived walking distance and effort, (2) street-level vegetation provides psychological restoration and stress reduction during walking, (3) green corridors serve as wayfinding cues and destination attractors, and (4) foreground vegetation creates a sense of enclosure and comfort that encourages pedestrian activity. The positive association between GVI and walking odds suggests that visible greenery at human scale acts as a behavioral nudge for active mobility choices.

source.citation: Lu, Y. (2018). The Association of Urban Greenness and Walking Behavior: Using Google Street View and Deep Learning Techniques to Estimate Residents' Exposure to Urban Greenness. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(8), 1576.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street-level vegetation (trees, shrubs, and vertical greenery) along pedestrian routes within 400m residential buffers to maximize visible greenness from eye-level perspectives in high-density urban contexts.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street greenness at foreground viewing distances creates visually appealing walking environments that encourage prolonged pedestrian activity. The immediate presence of vegetation in the walker's visual field improves aesthetic quality, provides psychological restoration benefits, and increases perceived safety and comfort, thereby extending total walking duration among residents.

source.citation: Lu, Y. (2018). The Association of Urban Greenness and Walking Behavior: Using Google Street View and Deep Learning Techniques to Estimate Residents' Exposure to Urban Greenness. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(8), 1576.

operation.description: Reduce foreground vegetation density in cycling corridors to maintain moderate GVI levels (avoiding excessive visual enclosure). Strategic thinning of street-level vegetation to ensure visual openness and sight lines while preserving green aesthetic benefits for cyclists.

pathway.mechanism_description: High GVI creates visual obstruction and perceived enclosure that restrains cycling activity. Excessive foreground vegetation reduces wayfinding clarity, limits sight distances for safety assessment, and creates psychological barriers. Moderate vegetation density balances greenness appreciation with spatial legibility, encouraging cycling behavior by maintaining visual permeability and perceived accessibility along cycling routes.

source.citation: Luo, P., Yu, B., Li, P., & Liang, P. (2022). Spatially varying impacts of the built environment on physical activity from a human-scale view: Using street view data. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10.

operation.description: Reduce street tree canopy density and visual coverage in foreground view to optimize green view index in old town areas, particularly for running activity zones. Control tree size and prune excessive foliage to maintain moderate visual greenery levels.

pathway.mechanism_description: The nonlinear relationship between GVI and running behavior suggests excessive visual greenery in constrained old town streets may create perception of limited space, poor ventilation, or safety concerns. Reducing foreground tree canopy size decreases visual enclosure, improves sightlines and perceived openness, potentially enhancing running comfort. The spatially varying impact indicates area-specific GVI thresholds exist where reduction improves running conditions.

source.citation: Luo, P., Yu, B., Li, P., & Liang, P. (2022). Spatially varying impacts of the built environment on physical activity from a human-scale view: Using street view data. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10.

operation.description: Increase the percentage and coverage of visible vegetation elements in street-level views through strategic addition of greenery in the foreground zone, targeting enhanced visual exposure to green infrastructure within pedestrian sightlines to elevate neighborhood environmental quality perception.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher Green View Index (GVI) serves as a visible indicator of neighborhood investment and environmental quality, with increased foreground vegetation coverage directly correlating with reduced urban poverty markers (IMD). The visual presence of greenery signals community care, investment in public realm, and environmental amenity access, which are inversely associated with deprivation indices. Street-level greenery visibility functions as both physical infrastructure improvement and social equity indicator.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Xing, H., Yuan, Y., Wong, M. S., & Fan, K. (2020). Sensing urban poverty: From the perspective of human perception-based greenery and open-space landscapes. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 84, 101544.

operation.description: Redistribute vegetation elements across urban areas to minimize spatial aggregation and ensure equitable geographic distribution, targeting areas with high poverty indices and low green space access to reduce environmental inequality.

pathway.mechanism_description: By reducing the spatial aggregation of greenery (IND_AGG_GRN) through strategic redistribution, this intervention addresses environmental justice issues captured by the Index of Multiple Deprivations (IMD). More evenly distributed vegetation improves access to green spaces in deprived neighborhoods, mitigating the clustering effect where affluent areas monopolize green infrastructure. The positive correlation with social performance (PRF_SOC) suggests that reduced aggregation enhances equity in ecosystem service delivery, psychological well-being, and community cohesion across socioeconomic strata.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Xing, H., Yuan, Y., Wong, M. S., & Fan, K. (2020). Sensing urban poverty: From the perspective of human perception-based greenery and open-space landscapes. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 84, 101544.

operation.description: Increase the proportion and coverage of vegetation elements (including trees and grass) in the foreground visual field to enhance the green view index (GVI) and create a more nature-dominant visual environment.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation proportion in the foreground increases visual exposure to natural elements, which triggers positive psychological responses through biophilic mechanisms. The increased green visual mass reduces visual clutter from built environment, enhances perceived naturalness, and improves visual comfort by providing softer textures and cooler color tones that are inherently preferred by human visual perception systems.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Preserve or enhance the visible extent of sky vault by controlling vertical obstruction elements in the background layer, thereby maximizing the Sky View Factor (SVF) within the viewing field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased sky visibility (higher SVF) enhances spatial openness perception, reduces feelings of enclosure and oppression, promotes psychological comfort through improved access to natural light and visual connection with the atmosphere, ultimately generating positive affective responses and higher perception scores.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Increase the diversity of vegetation types (trees, shrubs, grasses, and herbaceous plants) within the foreground visual field to create a heterogeneous vegetative composition with varied forms, textures, and spatial arrangements.

pathway.mechanism_description: Vegetation diversity enhances visual texture complexity and landscape richness, which positively influences aesthetic perception through increased visual interest and sensory stimulation. A mix of different plant forms (vertical trees, medium-height shrubs, low grasses) creates layered visual depth and textural variation that machine-learning models associate with higher visual comfort scores. This compositional heterogeneity reduces visual monotony and provides dynamic focal points that engage viewer attention, thereby improving predicted aesthetic performance.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Increase tree canopy coverage and density in street foreground to reduce Sky View Factor (SVF) from high values (>0.6) to moderate-low values (0.3-0.5), creating enhanced overhead shading through infill planting of large-canopy street trees

pathway.mechanism_description: Reducing SVF through increased tree canopy coverage blocks direct solar radiation exposure during summer periods, decreases mean radiant temperature (MRT), and creates cooler microclimates that improve comprehensive thermal comfort scores for pedestrians in summer-hot urban climates. Lower SVF values correspond to reduced sky hemisphere visibility and greater shading protection

source.citation: Ni, Y., Lin, L., Xia, H., & Wang, X. (2025). Urban Street Greening and Resident Comfort: An Integrated Approach Based on High-Precision Shadow Distribution and Facade Visual Assessment. Sustainability, 17(3), 1026.

operation.description: Optimize building height-to-street width ratios to maintain high Sky View Factor (SVF ≥ 0.6) in quasi-residential districts. Establish design guidelines that proportionally relate building heights to adjacent road widths, ensuring sufficient sky openness while accommodating urban density requirements.

pathway.mechanism_description: By controlling the dimensional relationship between building height (vertical element) and street width (horizontal distance), this optimization directly regulates the visible sky hemisphere from ground level. Lower height-to-width ratios reduce vertical obstruction angles, thereby increasing SVF values and enhancing perceived openness in residential environments. This geometric relationship creates a predictable correlation between built form dimensions and sky exposure metrics.

source.citation: Nishio, S., & Ito, F. (2019). Application of Method for Calculating Sky View Factor Using Google Street View: Relation Between Sky View Factor and Physical Elements in Urban Space. Proceedings of the ICA, 2, 1–8.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation density and green visual index (GVI) within a 2000m buffer zone of the target area by adding trees, shrubs, and vertical greenery systems along streets and public spaces to enhance overall greenery texture at eye-level perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street-level vegetation density increases the leaf surface area available for PM2.5 filtration and deposition. The increased GVI indicates greater greenery visibility and coverage in the pedestrian viewshed, which correlates with higher particulate matter capture efficiency through foliar uptake, dry deposition, and turbulence reduction. The 2000m buffer represents the effective spatial scale at which vegetation influences local air quality through pollutant dispersion and microclimate modification.

source.citation: O'Regan, A. C., Byrne, R., Hellebust, S., & Nyhan, M. M. (2022). Associations between Google Street View-derived urban greenspace metrics and air pollution measured using a distributed sensor network. Sustainable Cities and Society, 87, 104221.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of vegetation elements in the foreground of streetscapes, enhancing the Green View Index through strategic placement of plants, trees, shrubs, or vertical greenery within pedestrian sightlines.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI achieved through increased foreground vegetation directly enhances visual exposure to natural elements, which triggers psychological restoration responses. The prominence of green elements in the visual field reduces cognitive load, promotes attention restoration, and evokes associations with natural, tranquil environments, thereby elevating subjective perceptions of calmness and greenery (Class 2 perception scores).

source.citation: Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

operation.description: Maximize visible sky area by protecting and expanding openness in the background spatial layer, avoiding visual obstruction from tall vegetation or structures in upper view zones.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher Sky View Factor increases the proportion of unobstructed sky hemisphere visible from ground level, which enhances perceived openness and spatial transparency. This visual connection to the sky creates psychological associations with natural environments and reduces feelings of enclosure, thereby strengthening subjective perceptions of calmness and greenery ambiance (Class 2 restorative qualities).

source.citation: Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

operation.description: Morph building massing and urban form configuration in the background layer to increase the sky view factor through strategic manipulation of building heights, setbacks, and block spatial arrangements while maintaining functional density requirements.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased Sky View Factor (SVF) through building morphology optimization enhances visual openness and spatial permeability at street level, which negatively correlates with Walk Score as higher SVF may indicate lower density of walkable destinations and reduced facility accessibility within proximity. The negative relationship suggests that excessive sky openness may reflect dispersed urban form with fewer amenities

source.citation: Fang, Q., Inoue, T., ZHIQIU, X., & Qiang, L. (2022). Street Sky Openness Estimation Based on Deep Learning——Case Study of Hakata Station Area, Fukuoka. Proceedings of the 58th ISOCARP World Planning Congress.

operation.description: Increase tree canopy coverage in the background spatial tier to reduce sky view factor (SVF) and create enhanced vertical enclosure within the streetscape viewing cone

pathway.mechanism_description: Reducing SVF through strategic tree canopy expansion diminishes excessive sky exposure, creating a more enclosed and intimate spatial quality that enhances subjective aesthetic preference by providing visual balance, sense of protection, and appropriate spatial definition at the street level

source.citation: Qiu, W., Li, W., Liu, X., & Huang, X. (2022). Subjectively Measured Streetscape Qualities for Shanghai with Large-Scale Application of Computer Vision and Machine Learning. Proceedings of the 2021 DigitalFUTURES, 242–251.

operation.description: Optimize the dimensional allocation and spatial configuration of pedestrian walkways by expanding pavement width, ensuring adequate separation from vehicular traffic zones, and maximizing continuous pedestrian circulation space to accommodate comfortable walking speeds and densities.
