pathway.mechanism_description: Increased walkway size enhances spatial quality perception through multiple pathways: (1) provides sufficient physical space for pedestrian flow reducing congestion stress, (2) creates psychological distance buffer from vehicular hazards improving perceived safety, (3) enables comfortable walking speeds and social distancing contributing to positive walking experience, and (4) allows for visual openness in the foreground territory that street view imagery can capture as enhanced spatial quality metrics.

source.citation: Rui, Q., & Cheng, H. (2023). Quantifying the spatial quality of urban streets with open street view images: A case study of the main urban area of Fuzhou. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111204.

operation.description: Select and plant tree species with high canopy structures, arching branches, and broad crown forms to maximize overhead green view index (GVI) along pedestrian pathways and recreational routes. Prioritize species with dense foliage and wide-spreading canopies (e.g., Zelkova, Platanus) that create continuous overhead greenery visible from eye-level perspective. Position trees at 6-10m intervals along walkways to ensure canopy overlap and maximize angular green coverage in upper visual fields.

pathway.mechanism_description: Overhead tree canopies increase the angular green view index by occupying upper portions of the visual field (30-60° elevation angles), creating a psychologically comforting 'green tunnel' effect that enhances aesthetic pleasure and perceived safety during walking. This overhead greenery provides visual continuity, shade provision, and enclosure that encourages longer duration leisure walking by improving thermal comfort and creating more inviting pedestrian environments. The canopy structure acts as a natural visual guide that defines walking routes and enhances wayfinding.

source.citation: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T., Nakaya, N., Hozawa, A., & Nakaya, T. (2023). Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: A cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. International Journal of Health Geographics, 22(1).

operation.description: Implement selective canopy pruning to elevate the vertical distribution of tree foliage by removing lower branches and maintaining crown density at eye level and above (1.5-4m height). Focus on street trees and pedestrian corridor vegetation to reduce foreground visual obstruction while preserving overhead canopy cover.

pathway.mechanism_description: Raising tree canopy height reduces eye-level green visual incidence (GVI at pedestrian viewing angles), which negatively correlates with leisure walking time. Lower foreground GVI may decrease perceived enclosure and visual engagement with nature along walking routes, thereby reducing motivation for recreational walking. The mechanism operates through diminished visual contact with accessible greenery that typically stimulates leisure physical activity.

source.citation: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T., Nakaya, N., Hozawa, A., & Nakaya, T. (2023). Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: A cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. International Journal of Health Geographics, 22(1).

operation.description: Utilize Mapillary open-source street-level imagery combined with Mask2Former deep learning segmentation model to calculate Green View Index (GVI) by quantifying the proportion of visible vegetation in the foreground visual field from pedestrian perspective across urban streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Street-level image segmentation enables precise measurement of visible vegetation size (proportion) within the human visual field at foreground level. GVI calculated from Mapillary images provides a direct assessment of aesthetic-experiential performance by quantifying greenery visibility as perceived by pedestrians, which correlates with visual comfort, perceived naturalness, and restorative environmental quality. The automated segmentation approach allows scalable analysis across extensive urban networks to identify areas with deficient green visibility.

magnitude.value: descriptive: GVI calculation method using equation 2 (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Sánchez, I. A. V., & Labib, S. M. (2024). Accessing eye-level greenness visibility from open-source street view images: A methodological development and implementation in multi-city and multi-country contexts. Sustainable Cities and Society, 103, 105262.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street vegetation (trees, shrubs, and groundcover plants) in the foreground visual zone along urban streets, particularly targeting areas with low greenery ratios identified through street view imagery analysis across Chinese megacities.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced vegetation density in the immediate visual field (foreground) improves perceived visual comfort through multiple pathways: (1) biophilic response triggering positive psychological associations with nature; (2) visual softening of hard urban surfaces reducing harshness; (3) introduction of organic forms and varied textures creating visual complexity and interest; (4) provision of seasonal color variation breaking monotony; (5) creation of layered depth perception enhancing spatial richness. The foreground placement maximizes visual impact as these elements occupy a significant portion of the observer's field of view at street level, directly influencing aesthetic perception scores on the 1-5 Likert scale as measured in Shao et al.'s cross-city comparative analysis.

source.citation: Shao, Y., Yin, Y., Xue, Z., & Ma, D. (2023). Assessing and Comparing the Visual Comfort of Streets across Four Chinese Megacities Using AI-Based Image Analysis and the Perceptive Evaluation Method. Land, 12(4), 834.

operation.description: Frame and integrate distant mountain topography as visual backdrop in street design to create layered spatial depth and natural visual terminus, enhancing streetscape composition through background terrain features.

pathway.mechanism_description: Visible mountain terrain in background provides natural visual reference points and spatial orientation cues that reduce visual monotony. The distinctive silhouette shapes of distant topography create visual rhythm and memorable landmarks, enhancing perceived visual comfort through biophilic connection to natural landforms and improved legibility of urban space.

source.citation: Shao, Y., Yin, Y., Xue, Z., & Ma, D. (2023). Assessing and Comparing the Visual Comfort of Streets across Four Chinese Megacities Using AI-Based Image Analysis and the Perceptive Evaluation Method. Land, 12(4), 834.

operation.description: Adjust the proportional size of vegetation elements in the street view to achieve balanced visual composition where greenery, sky, and building features share equal visual field (approaching 1:1:1 ratio). Modify foreground vegetation coverage to optimize the Green View Index while maintaining visual equilibrium among major streetscape components.

pathway.mechanism_description: Balanced proportions of greenery, sky, and building elements in the visual field enhance perceived street livability by creating a harmonious aesthetic experience. Equal distribution of these three primary visual components (approximately 33% each) prevents visual dominance by any single element, reducing monotony from excessive buildings or overwhelming vegetation. This equilibrium promotes positive aesthetic perception and psychological comfort, as the Green View Index at moderate levels (around 30-35%) combined with balanced sky and building views creates optimal visual diversity and spatial openness, contributing to higher street livability ratings.

source.citation: Shen, Q., Zeng, W., Ye, Y., Arisona, S. M., Schubiger, S., Burkhard, R., & Qu, H. (2018). StreetVizor: Visual Exploration of Human-Scale Urban Forms Based on Street Views. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 24(1), 1004–1013.

operation.description: Optimize the spatial proportion of walkway elements (sidewalks, pedestrian fences) relative to vehicular road pavement in the streetscape foreground to increase walkway visual dominance and perceived accessibility.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing the relative size/proportion of pedestrian infrastructure elements enhances visual cues of walkability by: (1) strengthening pedestrian-scale spatial definition, (2) improving legibility of pedestrian circulation zones, (3) reducing visual dominance of vehicular spaces, and (4) signaling prioritization of walking activity, collectively enhancing perceived walkability as measured through streetscape perception surveys.

source.citation: Tao, Y., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Tian, G., & Zhang, S. (2022). Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land, 11(3), 400.

operation.description: Optimize tree placement and canopy positioning to maximize vertical coverage within the 0-30 degree viewing angle zone from typical pedestrian eye height (1.5-1.7m). This involves strategic placement of trees at appropriate distances from viewing points and selection of species with canopy heights that occupy this optimal visual range, considering both the vertical angle geometry and horizontal distance relationships.

pathway.mechanism_description: Trees positioned to occupy the 0-30 degree vertical viewing angle create optimal visual greenery perception by aligning with the natural comfortable viewing zone of human vision. This angle range corresponds to the most frequently scanned visual field during pedestrian movement, where green canopy elements are perceived with minimal neck strain and maximum visual acuity. The strategic positioning enhances the Tree View Factor (TVF) by ensuring canopy mass appears within this preferential viewing cone, thereby maximizing aesthetic appreciation and perceived greenness without requiring upward gaze adjustments that reduce visual comfort.

source.citation: Tong, Z., & Gong, C. (2022). Integrating Characteristics of Vertical Viewing Angle into Quantitative Analysis of Street View Photos. 2022 29th International Conference on Geoinformatics, 1–6.

source_indicator.current_value: Low (e.g., 0.376 in Old City branch roads)

operation.description: Add understory vegetation layers (shrubs and herbaceous plants) to increase vertical structural complexity in the foreground vegetation stratum, creating multi-layered plant communities beneath existing tree canopies along street corridors.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased vegetation structural diversity (VSD) through understory addition creates visual clutter and textural complexity in the foreground, which reduces visual penetration depth and occludes sight lines. The multi-layered vegetation structure fragments the visual field, thereby decreasing the Green View Index (GVI) by reducing the visible proportion of green canopy in street-level eye-height photography. Higher structural heterogeneity correlates negatively with simplified green visibility metrics.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Increase IND_VSD without necessarily increasing GVI drastically.

source.citation: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

operation.description: Implement vertical greening systems (green walls, climbing plants on facades) and modular box planting (elevated planters, container gardens) along branch roads in high-density old city districts where horizontal planting space is constrained by narrow sidewalks and utility infrastructure.

pathway.mechanism_description: Addition of vertical and containerized vegetation in the foreground tier increases the visible green surface area within the street canyon's visual field, directly elevating Green View Index (GVI) measurements captured from pedestrian eye-level perspectives. This strategy compensates for limited ground-level planting space by expanding greenery into the vertical dimension of building facades and deploying portable planting systems that maximize greenery density per unit of available horizontal space.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Old City mean=0.152, New City mean=0.196 (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

operation.description: Increase the proportion and coverage of natural elements, primarily vegetation and water features, within the foreground visual field to enhance naturalness perception in urban surroundings

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher proportion of natural elements in the foreground reduces visual complexity and artificial stimuli, triggering biophilic responses that facilitate attention restoration through soft fascination, lower physiological stress markers (cortisol, heart rate), and enhance overall psychological well-being and environmental satisfaction

source.citation: Verma, D., Jana, A., & Ramamritham, K. (2018). Quantifying Urban Surroundings Using Deep Learning Techniques: A New Proposal. Urban Science, 2(3), 78.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and canopy size of street trees and vertical greenery elements in core urban districts with low existing GVI values (e.g., Yau Tsim Mong, Hong Kong), focusing on pedestrian-level visual exposure at eye-level (1.5-2m height) along primary walkways and street frontages.

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding foreground trees at pedestrian eye-level directly increases the Green View Index by expanding the proportion of vegetation pixels captured in horizontal viewshed analysis. Larger canopy sizes and strategic placement in high-density, low-GVI districts maximizes visual green exposure, improving perceived greening distribution across the urban fabric and enhancing environmental performance through increased biophilic visual contact.

source.citation: Wang, H., & van Ameijde, J. (2023). Quantifying the Impact of Pedestrian-level Greening on the Perception of Walking. CAADRIA Proceedings, 2, 451–460.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street trees in the foreground of lower socioeconomic neighborhoods through systematic tree planting programs along streets, sidewalks, and pedestrian zones to achieve equitable distribution of green view index across different neighborhood SES levels.

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding street trees in the foreground increases the size/quantity of visible greenness captured in street view imagery (Green View Index). This directly addresses the environmental inequity documented by Wang et al. (2021), where lower SES neighborhoods exhibited significantly lower street view greenness. Foreground vegetation has the strongest visual impact on perceived greenness and provides immediate canopy coverage, enhancing both objective greenness metrics and subjective environmental quality for residents in disadvantaged communities.

source.citation: Wang, R., Feng, Z., Pearce, J., Yao, Y., Li, X., & Liu, Y. (2021). The distribution of greenspace quantity and quality and their association with neighbourhood socioeconomic conditions in Guangzhou, China: A new approach using deep learning method and street view images. Sustainable Cities and Society, 66, 102664.

operation.description: Increase Green View Index (GVI) in outdoor activity spaces by adding low-height vegetation elements including trees and shrubs to enhance visual greenery coverage within pedestrian eye-level sightlines (1.5-1.7m height). Focus on strategic placement of vegetation to maximize visible green surfaces from typical viewing positions in frequently used outdoor spaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI achieved through increased foreground vegetation provides enhanced shading, evapotranspiration cooling, and wind speed modification at the pedestrian level. The visual presence of greenery in the immediate foreground creates psychological cooling effects while the physical presence of vegetation intercepts solar radiation and releases latent heat through evapotranspiration, directly reducing ambient air temperature and mean radiant temperature (MRT) within the microclimate zone. This combined physiological and psychological effect leads to improved thermal comfort as measured by lower Thermal Comfort Vote (TCV) scores on the ASHRAE scale, indicating a negative correlation between GVI and thermal discomfort.

source.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

operation.description: Increase Tree View Factor (TVF) by strategically planting trees with dense, broad canopies in the background layer to maximize visible green coverage from pedestrian viewpoints. Prioritize evergreen species in winter months and deciduous species with high leaf area density in summer to maintain year-round visual presence.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher TVF increases the proportion of trees visible in the field of view, which enhances perceived thermal comfort through psychological cooling effects and visual association with shade. The negative direction (DIR_NEG) indicates that increased TVF correlates with lower Thermal Comfort Vote values, suggesting improved comfort perception. Dense canopies maximize the visual green volume while providing psychological relief from urban heat stress, even when direct shading may not be present at the observation point.

source.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street trees within 1-4km radius of central urban sites to enhance vertical street greening (measured as Green View Index - GVI). Focus on establishing continuous tree canopy along street corridors at the pedestrian eye-level viewshed to maximize visible greenery from street perspectives.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street tree coverage increases the Green View Index (GVI), which represents the proportion of vegetation visible from human eye level. Higher GVI correlates with reduced Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) concentrations through multiple pathways: (1) increased leaf surface area for NO2 absorption and dry deposition, (2) altered street canyon microclimate that affects pollutant dispersion patterns, (3) vegetative barriers that intercept vehicular emissions before reaching pedestrian zones, and (4) potential reduction in surface temperatures that indirectly affects photochemical reaction rates of NOx species.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Decrease in NO2, PM10, PM2.5, AQI

source.citation: Wu, D., Gong, J., Liang, J., Sun, J., & Zhang, G. (2020). Analyzing the Influence of Urban Street Greening and Street Buildings on Summertime Air Pollution Based on Street View Image Data. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 9(9), 500.

operation.description: Optimize building volume index (BVI) in street canyons by controlling vertical building density to maintain appropriate building-to-street width ratios that facilitate natural ventilation and pollutant dispersion. Avoid excessive vertical mass that creates confined air spaces at pedestrian level.

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower BVI values reduce vertical obstruction in street canyons, allowing improved air circulation and dilution of traffic-generated NO2 emissions. Excessive building vertical density creates canyon effects that trap pollutants at ground level. The study found non-significant correlation between BVI and NO2 concentration, suggesting BVI optimization should be considered alongside other morphological factors (sky view factor, street orientation) rather than as a standalone intervention for air quality improvement.

source.citation: Wu, D., Gong, J., Liang, J., Sun, J., & Zhang, G. (2020). Analyzing the Influence of Urban Street Greening and Street Buildings on Summertime Air Pollution Based on Street View Image Data. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 9(9), 500.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation coverage in densely populated areas and urban outskirts by adding trees and tall shrubs along sidewalks, building setbacks, and roadside buffers to enhance green view index at eye-level perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding foreground vegetation increases the proportion of greenery visible within the pedestrian view cone (0-180° horizontal field), directly elevating GVI values. The negative direction with Quality (PC4) suggests that excessive foreground greenery may obstruct visual access to higher-quality background landscapes or create monotonous green walls. Strategic placement should balance GVI enhancement with maintaining visual permeability to mid- and background elements that contribute to overall aesthetic quality.

source.citation: Wu, Z., Xu, K., Li, Y., Zhao, X., & Qian, Y. (2024). Application of an Integrated Model for Analyzing Street Greenery through Image Semantic Segmentation and Accessibility: A Case Study of Nanjing City. Forests, 15(3), 561.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation coverage to achieve Green View Index (GVI) exceeding 30% threshold through strategic addition of trees, shrubs, and vertical greenery along pedestrian viewsheds in foreground zones.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced foreground vegetation increases visual contact with nature in immediate viewing range, triggering biophilic responses that elevate subjective satisfaction and generate positive psychological feelings through stress reduction, attention restoration, and improved environmental quality perception. The 30% GVI threshold represents a critical tipping point where residents perceive sufficient greenness to activate psychological benefits.

source.citation: Liu, W., Hu, X., Song, Z., & Yuan, X. (2023). Identifying the integrated visual characteristics of greenway landscape: A focus on human perception. Sustainable Cities and Society, 99, 104937.

operation.description: Increase the coverage area and density of vegetation (trees and grass) in public open spaces through strategic planting to enhance visual greenness in street-level views

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced vegetation coverage increases the visibility and prominence of natural elements in the visual field captured by street view imagery, which positively influences perceived environmental quality scores through biophilic response, improved aesthetic appeal, and strengthened sense of naturalness in urban spaces

source.citation: Chen, S., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Automatic assessment of public open spaces using street view imagery. Cities, 137, 104329.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage proportion of street trees in the foreground layer to enhance visual green density along streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher green view index (GVI) from increased tree presence creates visually richer natural elements that positively influence perceived beauty through biophilic responses. The adversarial scoring system (human-machine) validated that greater vegetation proportion correlates with enhanced aesthetic perception, likely mediated by increased visual complexity, natural color diversity, and softening of hard urban surfaces.

source.citation: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., Ren, S., Zhang, J., Song, X., & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents' psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

operation.description: Increase the amount and density of visible street vegetation (trees, shrubs, grass, and herbaceous plants) in the foreground and middleground of the pedestrian streetscape to maximize green view index (GVI) within the immediate visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher green view index in the street environment provides continuous visual contact with nature during daily activities, which reduces psychological stress through attention restoration and emotional regulation. The visible presence of vegetation in the foreground creates a restorative microenvironment that buffers urban stressors and promotes positive affect, thereby reducing depressive symptoms in elderly populations as measured by GDS-15 scores.

source.citation: Helbich, M., Yao, Y., Liu, Y., Zhang, J., Liu, P., & Wang, R. (2019). Using deep learning to examine street view green and blue spaces and their associations with geriatric depression in Beijing, China. Environment International, 126, 107–117.

operation.description: Increase the visibility and presence of blue spaces (water bodies, fountains, water features) in the foreground of street views by adding or enhancing water elements that are directly visible to pedestrians at eye level.

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater blue space visibility in the street view reduces geriatric depression scores (GDS-15) through restorative environmental effects. Water features provide visual fascination, reduce mental fatigue, and trigger positive emotional responses. The foreground presence ensures direct visual engagement during daily activities, promoting stress reduction and mood enhancement particularly beneficial for elderly populations vulnerable to depression.

source.citation: Helbich, M., Yao, Y., Liu, Y., Zhang, J., Liu, P., & Wang, R. (2019). Using deep learning to examine street view green and blue spaces and their associations with geriatric depression in Beijing, China. Environment International, 126, 107–117.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and density of street trees at eye level to enhance Green View Index (GVI) within 800m buffer zones in neighborhoods characterized by steep topography (Group 3). Prioritize tree placement along pedestrian routes, sidewalks, and public spaces to maximize visual exposure to greenery from street-level perspectives.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced eye-level green visibility in steep-slope environments creates psychologically restorative streetscapes that reduce perceived exertion and physical barriers associated with hilly terrain. The increased GVI provides visual incentives and environmental comfort that motivate residents to engage in vigorous physical activities despite topographic challenges, transforming steep slopes from deterrents into navigable, attractive exercise environments.

source.citation: Sun, P., Song, Y., & Lu, W. (2022). Effect of Urban Green Space in the Hilly Environment on Physical Activity and Health Outcomes: Mediation Analysis on Multiple Greenery Measures. Land, 11(5), 612.

operation.description: Increase eye-level green space visibility (GVI) through strategic addition of street trees, vertical greening systems on building facades, and foreground vegetation layers along pedestrian corridors to enhance visual greenness exposure in residents' daily viewing range (typically 1.5-2m height perspective).

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced eye-level greenery increases visual green space exposure during daily activities, which promotes outdoor physical activity, walking, and recreational behaviors. The psychological restoration effect of green views reduces stress-related eating behaviors while increased walkability and outdoor engagement contributes to higher energy expenditure, collectively leading to lower BMI and reduced obesity risk.

source.citation: Xiao, Y., Zhang, Y., Sun, Y., Tao, P., & Kuang, X. (2020). Does Green Space Really Matter for Residents' Obesity? A New Perspective From Baidu Street View. Frontiers in Public Health, 8.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation to achieve a minimum 30% Green View Index (GVI) threshold in pedestrian viewsheds, with focus on foreground greenery placement along sidewalks, street frontages, and eye-level viewing zones to ensure adequate visual green coverage for thermal and aesthetic comfort.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI (≥30%) creates a comfortable visual environment by increasing the proportion of green elements in human field of view, which reduces visual stress, provides psychological restoration benefits, and enhances perceived aesthetic quality through natural color contrast and visual softness. The 30% threshold represents a critical point where users perceive sufficient greenness for visual comfort and environmental satisfaction.

source.citation: Xiao, C., Shi, Q., & Gu, C.-J. (2021). Assessing the Spatial Distribution Pattern of Street Greenery and Its Relationship with Socioeconomic Status and the Built Environment in Shanghai, China. Land, 10(8), 871.

operation.description: Increase the visible vegetation coverage in the foreground view by adding trees, shrubs, and other greenery elements along street edges, building facades, and pedestrian zones to systematically enhance the Green View Index (GVI) from street-level perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI achieved through foreground vegetation addition enhances the Cooling Power Index (CP) by: (1) increasing direct shading of ground and built surfaces, reducing solar radiation absorption; (2) promoting evapotranspiration which consumes latent heat and cools surrounding air masses; (3) creating multiple vegetation layers that intercept and filter thermal radiation; and (4) establishing visual-thermal synergy where perceived greenness correlates with measurable temperature reduction in the microclimate.

source.citation: Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and spatial coverage of accessible vegetation in the foreground to maximize touchable green interfaces and enhance visual green volume from pedestrian viewpoints.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher Green View Index (GVI) through expanded foreground vegetation creates multi-sensory engagement opportunities (visual richness, tactile accessibility, proximity to nature), which triggers positive psychological responses including stress reduction, attention restoration, and enhanced emotional well-being as measured by Positive Response Index.

source.citation: Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

operation.description: Increase street tree canopy coverage and planting density along high-grade roads (arterials and highways) to compensate for lower baseline GVI values. Prioritize continuous tree rows with large-canopy species in medians and roadside buffers where road width permits greater greenery installation.

pathway.mechanism_description: The study revealed a negative correlation between road grade and GVI (r=-0.336, p<0.01), indicating that wider, faster roads systematically have lower visible greenery. Higher-grade roads typically feature expanded impervious surfaces and prioritize vehicular movement over pedestrian amenity, creating greenery deficits. By strategically adding vegetation—particularly trees with substantial canopy spread—in available planting zones (medians, setbacks), the intervention directly increases the proportion of greenery visible in street-view imagery, thereby elevating GVI values. This targets the spatial inequity where infrastructure hierarchy inversely affects aesthetic green exposure.

source.citation: Xue, C., Jin, C., Zhou, L., & Li, G. (2022). Exploring the distribution of city street greenery from eye-level: An application of Baidu Map panoramic images data. Geografisk Tidsskrift-Danish Journal of Geography, 122(1), 73–86.

operation.description: Maintain and preserve existing mature vegetation (especially large canopy trees) in older residential districts to sustain high Green View Index values accumulated through decades of growth. Priority should be given to protecting established street trees and vegetation that contribute significantly to foreground greenery perception.

pathway.mechanism_description: Older buildings are associated with higher GVI due to the maturity and size of surrounding vegetation that has accumulated over time. Maintaining these established plants preserves their canopy volume and visual prominence in street-level views. The negative correlation between building age and greenery distribution suggests that mature vegetation in historic districts creates higher perceived greenness, which would be lost if vegetation is removed or replaced with younger plantings.

source.citation: Xue, C., Jin, C., Zhou, L., & Li, G. (2022). Exploring the distribution of city street greenery from eye-level: An application of Baidu Map panoramic images data. Geografisk Tidsskrift-Danish Journal of Geography, 122(1), 73–86.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of visible street vegetation in the foreground view to enhance Green View Index (GVI) along street corridors through strategic tree planting, vertical greening, and shrub installation at eye-level viewing distances.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI values, achieved through increased visible greenery in the foreground viewing zone, enhance aesthetic visual quality as perceived by human observers. The mechanism operates through: (1) increased green color proportion in the visual field improving pleasantness, (2) biophilic responses to natural elements reducing stress, (3) visual complexity from vegetation texture enriching scene interest, and (4) softening of hard urban surfaces. Expert evaluations via Elo rating methodology confirm that street scenes with greater visible vegetation consistently receive higher aesthetic quality scores.

source.citation: Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street-level vegetation (trees, shrubs, and grass) along pedestrian corridors to enhance Green View Index (GVI) perceived by pedestrians at eye-level.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street greenery increases visual contact with nature during walking, which creates more aesthetically pleasant and psychologically restorative environments. Higher GVI values reduce perceived stress, increase route attractiveness, and provide perceived shade comfort, thereby encouraging residents to choose walking over motorized transport and engage in outdoor physical activities more frequently. The street-level vegetation acts as a positive environmental cue that promotes active transportation behaviors.

source.citation: Yin, C., Peng, N., Li, Y., Shi, Y., Yang, S., & Jia, P. (2023). A review on street view observations in support of the sustainable development goals. International Journal of Applied Earth Observation and Geoinformation, 117, 103205.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of eye-level vegetation (shrubs, hedgerows, vertical greenery) along pedestrian pathways to enhance green view index within the immediate visual field of walking individuals.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher green view index in the foreground visual field provides direct psychological restoration through attention restoration theory mechanisms. Eye-level greenery creates immediate visual contact with nature during pedestrian movement, reducing momentary stress levels by offering restorative stimuli that counteract environmental stressors and mental fatigue in real-time contexts.

source.citation: Yu, C., & Kwan, M.-P. (2024). Dynamic greenspace exposure, individual mental health status and momentary stress level: A study using multiple greenspace measurements. Health & Place, 86, 103213.

operation.description: Infill street corridors and pedestrian pathways with vegetation layers to increase green view index (GVI) at eye-level in lower-SES, high-density districts such as Sham Shui Po. Prioritize placement along primary walking routes to maximize visual contact frequency during daily mobility patterns.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased foreground vegetation exposure enhances green view index (GVI) encountered during routine activities, providing consistent visual access to nature that reduces cortisol levels and momentary stress through attention restoration and psychological distancing from urban stressors. The proximity effect of foreground greenery creates immediate perceptual relief that accumulates across multiple daily exposures.

source.citation: Yu, C., & Kwan, M.-P. (2024). Dynamic greenspace exposure, individual mental health status and momentary stress level: A study using multiple greenspace measurements. Health & Place, 86, 103213.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of eye-level street greenery (vegetation within 0-2m height range visible from pedestrian perspective) along walking routes, including street trees with low canopies, shrubs, hedges, green walls, and planters to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) in the foreground visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Eye-level street greenery in the foreground creates immediate visual contact with nature, enhancing aesthetic pleasure and psychological restoration for older adults during walking. The increased GVI provides continuous green scenery exposure that reduces perceived walking effort, improves thermal comfort through shade, and creates a more inviting pedestrian environment, thereby increasing walking duration and frequency. The foreground vegetation serves as a proximate stimulus that is more visually accessible and engaging than distant greenery, directly influencing walking behavior through enhanced environmental attractiveness.

source.citation: Zang, P., Liu, X., Zhao, Y., Guo, H., Lu, Y., & Xue, C. Q. L. (2020). Eye-Level Street Greenery and Walking Behaviors of Older Adults. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 17(17), 6130.

operation.description: Increase tree canopy coverage in urban streets to reduce Sky View Factor (SVF), creating overhead shading that blocks direct solar radiation from reaching road surfaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower SVF values (achieved through increased canopy coverage) reduce the amount of incoming solar radiation that reaches road surfaces, thereby decreasing Road Surface Temperature (RST). The positive directional relationship indicates that as SVF increases, RST increases; conversely, reducing SVF through canopy addition leads to cooler road surfaces by intercepting shortwave radiation and providing thermal comfort through shading.

source.citation: Zeng, L., Lindberg, F., Zhang, X., Pan, H., & Lu, J. (2023). Road surface temperature evaluated with streetview-derived parameters in a hot and humid megacity. Urban Climate, 51, 101585.

operation.description: Increase the proportion of wild flora including native bushes, dense groves, and naturalistic vegetation assemblages in the foreground, while reducing the coverage of manicured lawns and artificial ornamental plantings to create a more ecologically authentic landscape texture.

pathway.mechanism_description: Wild vegetation with irregular growth patterns, diverse textures, and naturalistic compositions enhances the perception of ecological authenticity and wildness. The tactile and visual complexity of unmanaged flora—including varied leaf structures, spontaneous growth patterns, and seasonal variations—creates immersive sensory experiences that strengthen visitors' sense of intimacy with nature by providing direct encounters with ecological processes rather than horticultural artifice.

source.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

operation.description: Install service facilities including benches, lighting fixtures, and informational signboards in the foreground zone to enhance spatial legibility and provide functional amenities that signal active maintenance and care.

pathway.mechanism_description: Service facilities function as tangible 'cues to care' that communicate ongoing stewardship and social order. The presence of well-maintained benches, adequate lighting, and clear signage enhances perceived safety, reduces ambiguity about space usage, and signals that the environment is monitored and valued. These visual cues reduce perceived risk and increase psychological comfort, thereby facilitating attention restoration by allowing users to feel secure enough to engage in restorative experiences. The facilities also support extended stay duration (fascination) and provide physical comfort necessary for stress recovery.

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Optimize green space exposure by increasing vegetation coverage within the middleground perception zone (street-level visible greenery), utilizing spatially-explicit grid-based measurement (rather than single-point buffer analysis) to capture the nonlinear dose-response relationship between Green View Index and psychological stress reduction.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced middleground green visibility creates perceptual contact with nature that reduces psychological stress through attention restoration and stress recovery pathways. The nonlinear relationship suggests threshold effects where moderate-to-high GVI levels (optimal dosage) provide maximum stress reduction benefits, while accounting for spatial heterogeneity in exposure patterns across residential neighborhoods prevents underestimation of health impacts.

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Optimize vegetation color composition in middle-ground views through diverse planting design with varied seasonal palettes and chromatic arrangements to enhance visual landscape aesthetic quality and scenic appeal.

pathway.mechanism_description: Diverse vegetation color patterns in middleground views create psychologically cooling effects through visual perception mechanisms: cooler color tones (blues, greens) and varied chromatic compositions reduce perceived thermal stress, enhance visual comfort, and trigger cognitive associations with shade and coolness, thereby improving thermal sensation ratings from 'much hotter' toward 'much cooler' despite unchanged physical temperature

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Minimize building footprint and reduce structural density in immediate vicinity of sports and recreational facilities to maximize Sky View Factor (SVF), ensuring unobstructed vertical visibility and enhanced spatial openness in exercise zones.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased SVF through building density reduction creates perceptually expansive outdoor environments with greater sky exposure. This enhanced visual openness reduces spatial confinement, improves psychological comfort, strengthens connection to nature, and promotes thermal comfort through better air circulation and natural ventilation. The resulting pleasant environmental conditions encourage longer exercise participation duration by reducing perceived exercise barriers and enhancing overall exercise experience quality.

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Reduce building density or visual barriers in sports and recreational areas to maximize sky visibility.

pathway.mechanism_description: Creating open athletic venues and plazas increases SVF, facilitating exercise.

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Increase the proportion of visible vegetation in the urban foreground view through strategic addition of vegetation elements, enhancing Green View Index (GVI) within the pedestrian sight line and street-level perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI directly reduces air temperature through multiple mechanisms: vegetation provides evapotranspiration cooling, increases surface albedo compared to built materials, creates shading effects that reduce solar heat absorption, and enhances air circulation. The visible green mass in foreground acts as a thermal buffer, intercepting shortwave radiation and releasing latent heat through transpiration, thereby lowering ambient air temperature in the immediate microclimate zone.

source.citation: Zhou, H., Tao, G., Yan, X., & Sun, J. (2021). Influences of greening and structures on urban thermal environments: A case study in Xuzhou City, China. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 66, 127386.

operation.description: Optimize street tree canopy coverage to achieve a minimum Green View Index (GVI) threshold of 30% for standard urban streets and 40% for high-quality green streets. This involves calibrating tree density, canopy size, and spacing along street corridors to maximize visible greenery from pedestrian eye-level perspective (1.6m height). Implementation should consider strategic placement in foreground viewing zones to enhance green visibility within the critical 0-50m viewing distance.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing tree canopy size and coverage in the foreground tier directly enhances the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level panoramic views, thereby elevating GVI scores. The 30-40% GVI thresholds correlate with measurable aesthetic improvements as larger tree canopies occupy greater visual field areas at pedestrian eye level. The foreground positioning (0-50m) ensures maximum visual impact, as greenery closer to viewers contributes disproportionately to perceived landscape quality and aesthetic satisfaction compared to background vegetation.

source.citation: Zhu, H., Nan, X., Yang, F., & Bao, Z. (2023). Utilizing the green view index to improve the urban street greenery index system: A statistical study using road patterns and vegetation structures as entry points. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104780.

operation.description: Add central greenery belts (median strips with vegetation) to road profiles, positioning green infrastructure in the middle ground layer of street cross-sections to maximize visual exposure from pedestrian and vehicular viewpoints.

pathway.mechanism_description: Central greenery belts directly occupy the visual field's middle ground, creating continuous green surfaces that are perpendicular to viewing angles along roads. This positioning strategy maximizes Green View Index (GVI) by ensuring vegetation appears prominently in street-level panoramic captures, particularly effective in wide road patterns where central medians provide substantial visual green coverage without obstruction from foreground elements.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Loop-shaped roads (GVI=0.271) > T-shaped roads (GVI=0.245) > Cul-de-sac roads (GVI=0.241) > Linear roads (GVI=0.227) (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhu, H., Nan, X., Yang, F., & Bao, Z. (2023). Utilizing the green view index to improve the urban street greenery index system: A statistical study using road patterns and vegetation structures as entry points. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104780.

operation.description: Prioritize Tree-Shrub (T-S) layered structures over Tree-Herb (T-H) configurations in foreground planting design. Implement multi-layered vegetation schemes that integrate shrub understory beneath tree canopies to maximize vertical green coverage and visual density.

pathway.mechanism_description: Shrub layers significantly enhance Green View Index (GVI) by filling the critical mid-height visual zone (0.5-3m) that remains empty in T-H structures. The combination of tree canopy and shrub mass creates continuous vertical greenery that occupies a larger proportion of the human field of view at eye level, thereby increasing perceived green coverage. Shrubs provide denser foliage texture and more consistent year-round visual presence compared to herbaceous layers, resulting in higher GVI measurements across seasons. The structural complexity of T-S configurations maximizes green pixels captured in street-level imagery used for GVI assessment.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Tree layer contributed most (mean 42.6%), followed by shrub layer (31.8%) and herb layer (25.6%) to total GVI (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhu, H., Nan, X., Yang, F., & Bao, Z. (2023). Utilizing the green view index to improve the urban street greenery index system: A statistical study using road patterns and vegetation structures as entry points. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104780.

operation.description: In early-stage road construction planning, prioritize immediate shrub planting along roadside foreground zones rather than waiting for long-term tree canopy maturation. This strategic sequencing considers the temporal development patterns of vegetation layers to accelerate green view coverage.

pathway.mechanism_description: Shrubs achieve visual coverage and canopy closure within 2-3 years, providing immediate GVI improvement in the pedestrian viewshed foreground (0-5m height range). This approach addresses the 10-20 year maturation gap of tree canopies, ensuring continuous green visibility during early road life cycles. The lower-height vegetation layer (shrubs) fills the critical visual zone at eye-level and immediately above, which contributes disproportionately to street-level GVI measurements compared to sparse young tree crowns.

source.citation: Zhu, H., Nan, X., Yang, F., & Bao, Z. (2023). Utilizing the green view index to improve the urban street greenery index system: A statistical study using road patterns and vegetation structures as entry points. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104780.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of visible vegetation elements (trees, shrubs, and grass) along running routes to enhance Green View Index (GVI) in the foreground visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI creates visually enriched and biophilic running environments that attract runners through enhanced aesthetic appeal, perceived naturalness, and psychological restoration benefits. The presence of visible greenery in the foreground visual field increases route preference and usage frequency, as evidenced by elevated running trajectory density in areas with greater vegetation visibility.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Higher running trajectory density observed in areas with higher GVI (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

operation.description: Selectively prune tree canopy branches to reduce overhead coverage and maintain Sky View Factor above 0.2 in wooded areas, ensuring adequate sky visibility while preserving tree health and structural integrity.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing Sky View Factor through canopy excision enhances perceived spatial openness and reduces visual enclosure, creating a more inviting and less confined walking environment. Higher SVF (>0.2) improves ambient light penetration, enhances wayfinding clarity, and reduces psychological stress associated with heavily enclosed spaces, thereby positively influencing walking preference and pedestrian pathway selection behavior.

source.citation: Zou, J., Jiang, H., Ying, W., & Qiu, B. (2024). Scenic Influences on Walking Preferences in Urban Forest Parks from Top-View and Eye-Level Perspectives. Forests, 15(11), 2020.

operation.description: Increase street-level vegetation (trees and grass) to enhance color richness and visual diversity in high-density urban street environments, focusing on foreground plantings that contribute to the visible color palette from pedestrian viewpoints.

pathway.mechanism_description: Addition of diverse vegetation species increases the chromatic complexity and color richness of the street scene, which positively correlates with visual openness (Sky View Index) by creating perceptual depth and visual interest. The multi-layered greenery provides contrasting hues (green foliage, seasonal colors) against built environment backgrounds, enhancing aesthetic performance through improved color diversity indices and visual quality perception in constrained urban spaces.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Prioritize vegetation addition interventions in identified 'Cold Spots' (low GVI areas) within central city regions and suburban cores to address spatial heterogeneity of greenery distribution. Increase vegetation coverage in residential communities showing deficit green view index values based on hot/cold spot analysis.

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding vegetation in cold spot areas directly increases the Green View Index (GVI) by expanding the visible greenery from street-level perspective. This strategic spatial intervention reduces heterogeneity by elevating greenery levels in underserved areas, thereby improving overall aesthetic performance and visual green exposure equity across residential communities. The background-scale vegetation enhancement creates cohesive green visual environments.

source.citation: Song, J., Zhu, X., & Yu, X. (2023). Monitoring and mapping vegetation greenery in residential communities using street view images and a Normalized Vegetation Greenery Index: A case study in Beijing, China. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 6.

operation.description: In high GVI streets (>0.6), optimize vegetation design by diversifying plant forms (e.g., columnar, spreading, weeping habits), varying species composition to create layered canopy structures, and introducing seasonal color variations through flowering species and foliage changes, rather than simply increasing vegetation quantity or coverage.

pathway.mechanism_description: Excessive vegetation monotony in high GVI environments can cause visual fatigue and reduced aesthetic satisfaction. Optimizing morphological diversity, structural complexity, and chromatic variation enhances visual interest and breaks monotonous green dominance. Diversified vegetation forms create rhythmic visual sequences, multi-layered textures provide depth perception, and color accents establish focal points, collectively improving visual comfort without compromising existing greenery coverage. The negative direction (DIR_NEG) indicates that merely maximizing GVI quantity degrades aesthetic performance, necessitating qualitative optimization strategies.

source.citation: Sun, D., Ji, X., Gao, W., Zhou, F., Yu, Y., Meng, Y., Yang, M., Lin, J., & Lyu, M. (2023). The Relation between Green Visual Index and Visual Comfort in Qingdao Coastal Streets. Buildings, 13(2), 457.

operation.description: Increase Green View Index to exceed the 30% threshold for favorable perception, particularly in suburban and newly developed areas.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing visible vegetation density in the immediate field of view.

source.citation: Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

operation.description: Strategically position vegetation elements to maximize visual exposure from pedestrian viewpoints, prioritizing eye-level green visibility over horizontal coverage. Concentrate green elements in foreground zones (0-20m viewing distance) along primary sightlines and circulation routes to enhance perceived greenness independent of total area metrics.

pathway.mechanism_description: The non-significant association between Green View Index (GVI) and green space coverage indicates that traditional area-based metrics poorly predict visual greening outcomes. GVI captures human-centered perception by quantifying the proportion of visible greenery in the visual field, which is predominantly influenced by foreground vegetation placement rather than distant or overhead canopy coverage. Strategic positioning of vegetation in immediate viewing zones creates higher perceived green exposure without proportional increases in land coverage, suggesting that spatial configuration and visual accessibility are more critical than quantity for aesthetic performance outcomes.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Increase GVI without necessarily increasing GCR

source.citation: Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

operation.description: Increase tree canopy coverage in foreground spaces to reduce Sky View Factor (SVF) through expanded vegetative screening of direct sky exposure.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher tree coverage decreases SVF by obstructing sky dome visibility, which reduces shortwave and longwave radiation exchange between ground surfaces and the sky hemisphere. This solar radiation interception and shading effect directly lowers Mean Radiant Temperature (Tmrt) by reducing radiative heat gain on pedestrian surfaces.

source.citation: Song, J., Zhu, X., & Yu, X. (2023). Monitoring and mapping vegetation greenery in residential communities using street view images and a Normalized Vegetation Greenery Index: A case study in Beijing, China. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 6.

operation.description: Utilize point-cloud based spatial mapping (grid analysis) rather than single center-point analysis to evaluate park visual characteristics accurately.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increases representativeness of the visual experience in dynamic movement.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Increased accuracy of visual characteristic representation

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street-level vegetation in areas identified with low GVI values (affecting 75% of the city area) through strategic planting of trees, shrubs, and vertical greenery along streets, sidewalks, and building facades to enhance visible greenery from pedestrian perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Addition of foreground vegetation directly increases the amount of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby improving GVI scores. Street trees and vegetation at eye-level create immediate visual impact in the foreground plane, which has the strongest influence on GVI calculation as it occupies larger proportions of street view imagery compared to middle or background elements. The increased vegetation coverage enhances environmental performance by improving visual quality, thermal comfort, and psychological well-being for urban residents.

magnitude.value: descriptive: 75.59% of areas have GVI levels in a specific range (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhang, A., Zhai, S., Liu, X., Song, G., & Feng, Y. (2022). Investigating the Association between Streetscapes and Mental Health in Zhanjiang, China: Using Baidu Street View Images and Deep Learning. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 19(24), 16634.

operation.description: Replace solid perimeter walls with transparent or semi-transparent railing fences, open metal grilles, or permeable facade systems to allow visual penetration and reveal interior green vegetation to street-level viewers.

pathway.mechanism_description: Replacing opaque boundary walls with transparent enclosures increases visual connectivity between private/semi-private greenspaces and public streetscapes. This transformation changes the texture (solidity to permeability) of foreground barriers, enabling previously hidden vegetation to contribute to street-level Green View Index. The enhanced visual penetration expands the effective green viewing field by incorporating background greenery that was previously occluded by solid walls, thereby increasing aggregate green visibility metrics without necessarily adding new vegetation.

source.citation: Zhu, J., Qiu, L., Su, Y., Guo, Q., Hu, T., Bao, H., Luo, J., Wu, S., Xu, Q., Wang, Z., & Pan, Y. (2022). Disentangling the effects of the surrounding environment on street-side greenery: Evidence from Hangzhou. Ecological Indicators, 143, 109153.

operation.description: Select and prioritize evergreen tree species (e.g., conifers, broadleaf evergreens) in the middleground layer to maintain consistent green coloration and visual continuity throughout seasonal transitions, particularly during winter dormancy periods when deciduous vegetation loses foliage

pathway.mechanism_description: Evergreen species retain foliage year-round, preserving the greenery-dominated visual character that defines stable visual walkability types across seasons. By maintaining consistent canopy color (VAR_COL) in the middle-ground view zone, the visual environment remains recognizable and predictable, preventing seasonal shifts from greenery-dominated to built-dominated or sky-dominated visual walkability categories. This stabilization supports consistent wayfinding and aesthetic continuity in urban walking environments.

predicted_effect.indicator_change: Maintain Type A classification in Winter

source.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

operation.description: Increase pavement area allocation within street cross-sections by widening sidewalk zones and reducing vehicular lane width, thereby increasing the pavement-to-road pixel ratio in street view imagery to create pedestrian-prioritized thoroughfares

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding pavement size through infill operations increases the visual presence of walkable surfaces in the foreground view, directly enhancing the Visible Pedestrian Index (VPI) by providing greater spatial availability for pedestrian movement. Larger pavement allocation improves perceived walkability and encourages active mobility behaviors by creating more comfortable, accessible pedestrian environments

source.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and canopy coverage of street trees in the foreground viewing zone to enhance Green View Index (GVI) at eye-level perspective, strategically placing trees along sidewalks and street edges to maximize visible greenery while managing sky view factor.

pathway.mechanism_description: Addition of foreground trees directly increases the proportion of vegetation pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby elevating the Green View Index score. The increased canopy size creates a more balanced visual composition by reducing excessive sky visibility, which improves perceived aesthetic quality through enhanced spatial enclosure and biophilic connection. Deep learning-based visual quality assessment identifies higher greenery proportions as positively correlated with human preference for streetscape aesthetics.

source.citation: Zhang, Q., Bu, J., & Yi, Y. (2021). Measuring Visual Quality of Street Space Based on Deep Learning and Street View Picture: Pilot in The Lilong Area in Shanghai. Proceedings of the 55th ISOCARP World Planning Congress.

operation.description: Modify the shape and configuration of natural vegetation elements in the middle ground to optimize visual composition and landscape aesthetic quality in urban green spaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Natural vegetation shape modifications in the middle ground enhance visual landscape scores by improving spatial hierarchy, creating visual interest through organic forms, and establishing harmonious natural patterns that increase aesthetic perception and visual preference among observers

magnitude.value: descriptive: Double-layer green roofs show higher visual landscape scores than single-layer in Figure 2a (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Add water features in the middleground to increase visual and textural diversity in urban green spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Water features enhance perceived restoration by providing natural textural elements that facilitate attention restoration through fascination and being away experiences. The visual and auditory qualities of water increase environmental preference and reduce mental fatigue, supporting psychological restoration processes aligned with Attention Restoration Theory.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Modify vegetation spatial configuration and composition patterns to enhance plant species diversity in urban green spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Vegetation configuration modifications (shape variations) were tested but showed no significant relationship with species diversity outcomes, suggesting that diversity may be more influenced by ecological management practices or species selection rather than spatial form alone

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of vegetation elements in the foreground viewing area to enhance green view index in urban streetscapes through strategic addition of plants.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding vegetation size in the foreground directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby elevating GVI measurements. Larger vegetation masses create more visible green surfaces that occupy greater visual angles from pedestrian viewpoints, resulting in higher restorative potential through enhanced nature exposure.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Increase the size and quantity of vegetation elements in the foreground and visible areas of the urban streetscape to enhance green visual index (GVI)

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater vegetation size and coverage in the foreground directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, which correlates positively with subjective perception of green quantity. Enhanced visual exposure to vegetation improves aesthetic perception scores through increased greenness visibility

source.citation: Cheng, L., Chu, S., Zong, W., Li, S., Wu, J., & Li, M. (2017). Use of Tencent Street View Imagery for Visual Perception of Streets. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 6(9), 265.

operation.description: Increase sky openness by reducing building height, width, or density in the background view to expand the visible sky area and improve sky view factor in the urban scene.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher sky view factor (SVF) creates more open and exposed spatial configurations that reduce visual enclosure. The increased visible sky area diminishes the sense of spatial definition and protective enclosure, leading to lower perceived safety scores as the environment feels more exposed and less territorially defined.

source.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

operation.description: Increase the proportion and coverage of visible vegetation elements in urban streetscapes to enhance Green View Index (GVI) across different spatial contexts.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI improves visual environmental quality by increasing natural elements in the field of view, which positively correlates with perceived safety (visibility and natural surveillance), wealth (environmental quality and maintenance), liveliness (biodiversity and seasonal variation), and beauty (aesthetic preference for nature) in urban spaces. The spatio-temporal evolution of GVI directly reflects changes in composite perceptual scores.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Safety(0.28), Wealthy(0.32), Lively(0.23), Beautiful(0.30) (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Liang, X., Zhao, T., & Biljecki, F. (2023). Revealing spatio-temporal evolution of urban visual environments with street view imagery. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104802.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of vegetation in the middle ground of urban visual fields to enhance green presence and naturalness within the viewing scene.

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater vegetation exposure reduces negative affect by providing restorative visual stimuli, activating parasympathetic nervous system responses, and facilitating attention restoration. The presence of natural elements in the mid-ground viewing distance creates an accessible layer of nature contact that buffers stress and promotes psychological restoration, thereby lowering scores on the negative affect subscale of PANAS.

source.citation: Liu, Y., Xiao, T., Liu, Y., Yao, Y., & Wang, R. (2021). Natural outdoor environments and subjective well-being in Guangzhou, China: Comparing different measures of access. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 59, 127027.

operation.description: Optimize vegetation diversity composition in the middleground to achieve balanced visual variety without exceeding perceptual saturation thresholds

pathway.mechanism_description: Moderate diversity levels in vegetation texture create optimal visual interest for aesthetic appreciation. Beyond saturation point, excessive diversity may reduce coherence and diminish aesthetic quality, suggesting an optimal range exists for landscape diversity

operation.description: Modify street network configuration and spatial layout to enhance visual distinctiveness and recognizability of route segments through improved geometric clarity and spatial hierarchy

pathway.mechanism_description: Optimized street segment shapes with clear geometric characteristics improve wayfinding cues and spatial recognition, enabling deep learning models to better classify and distinguish different route segments, thereby enhancing overall spatial legibility and navigation efficiency in public open spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street-level greenness visibility increases perceived environmental quality and aesthetic appeal, thereby motivating walking behavior through improved visual comfort and positive psychological responses to green environments
