operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of visible vegetation in the middleground streetscape to enhance green view index along pedestrian corridors and walking routes

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced visual greenness (measured by GVI) creates more attractive and pleasant walking environments that positively influence walking behavior, with gender-specific responses to increased green exposure in urban streets

source.citation: Lu, Y. (2018). The Association of Urban Greenness and Walking Behavior: Using Google Street View and Deep Learning Techniques to Estimate Residents' Exposure to Urban Greenness. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 15(8), 1576.

operation.description: Increase vegetation coverage and density along cycling routes and in surrounding urban areas to enhance the Ratio Vegetation Index (RVI) within the middleground visibility range of cyclists.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher RVI values create more visually pleasant and thermally comfortable cycling environments through increased greenery texture. The enhanced visual quality and shade provision encourages cycling behavior by making routes more attractive and reducing heat stress, thereby positively influencing the Cycling Index.

source.citation: Luo, P., Yu, B., Li, P., & Liang, P. (2022). Spatially varying impacts of the built environment on physical activity from a human-scale view: Using street view data. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10.

operation.description: Add and increase the size of tree canopy coverage in the background layer to reduce Sky View Factor (SVF) values in urban restoration areas

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing tree canopy size in the background reduces the proportion of visible sky hemisphere, thereby lowering SVF values. Lower SVF values are associated with improved restoration quality through enhanced sense of enclosure, reduced visual exposure to built elements, and creation of more intimate naturalistic environments conducive to psychological restoration

source.citation: Ma, H., Xu, Q., & Zhang, Y. (2023). High or low? Exploring the restorative effects of visual levels on campus spaces using machine learning and street view imagery. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 88, 128087.

operation.description: Increase building density and height in the background to reduce sky view factor, creating more enclosed urban street environments with higher building-to-sky ratios.

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower SVF values (resulting from increased building mass and enclosure) are positively associated with higher IMD scores, indicating that areas with more constrained sky visibility tend to correlate with multiple deprivation indicators including income, employment, health, and living environment barriers.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Xing, H., Yuan, Y., Wong, M. S., & Fan, K. (2020). Sensing urban poverty: From the perspective of human perception-based greenery and open-space landscapes. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 84, 101544.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of vegetation in the middleground viewing zone to enhance green view index (GVI) within the visual field

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation coverage in the middleground creates a more prominent green visual presence that enhances perceived beauty, safety, liveliness and overall environmental quality. The increased GVI provides visual comfort and biophilic benefits that positively influence psychological perception across multiple dimensions

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of visible vegetation in the middle ground of urban streetscapes to enhance Green View Index (GVI).

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation visibility reduces negative psychological perceptions (boring, depression) by introducing natural elements that provide visual interest, biophilic stimulation, and restorative environmental qualities that counteract monotony and psychological distress in urban settings.

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Addition of natural landscape elements with varied textures in the middleground to increase naturalness perception in urban environments

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing textural diversity through natural vegetation elements enhances perceived naturalness, which negatively correlates with psychological stress. The varied textures of natural landscapes (leaves, branches, ground cover) provide visual complexity and biophilic cues that reduce stress responses and improve positive perception scores

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Add natural vegetation elements with varied textures in the middleground to enhance visual richness and naturalness of the landscape scene

pathway.mechanism_description: Natural vegetation textures in the middleground increase visual complexity and biophilic qualities, creating more engaging and comfortable visual experiences that improve aesthetic perception scores

source.citation: Meng, Y., Shi, J., Lyu, M., Sun, D., & Fukuda, H. (2024). Research into the Influence Mechanisms of Visual-Comfort and Landscape Indicators of Urban Green Spaces. Land, 13(10), 1688.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of street vegetation in the foreground visual field to enhance Green View Index along urban streets

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation coverage in the immediate visual field increases perceived greenness (GVI), which provides psychological thermal comfort through visual cooling effects and actual thermal regulation through shading and evapotranspiration, collectively improving comprehensive thermal comfort scores

source.citation: Ni, Y., Lin, L., Xia, H., & Wang, X. (2025). Urban Street Greening and Resident Comfort: An Integrated Approach Based on High-Precision Shadow Distribution and Facade Visual Assessment. Sustainability, 17(3), 1026.

operation.description: Modify the size (height, width, or massing) of buildings in the middleground to alter the Sky View Factor along different road types

pathway.mechanism_description: Building size directly controls the proportion of visible sky hemisphere from ground level. Larger/taller buildings reduce SVF by occluding more sky area, while smaller/lower buildings increase SVF by allowing greater sky visibility. The relationship varies by road type due to differences in street width and building setbacks

magnitude.value: descriptive: SVF ~58% for collector roads, ~53% for local roads, ~42% for arterial roads (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Nishio, S., & Ito, F. (2019). Application of Method for Calculating Sky View Factor Using Google Street View: Relation Between Sky View Factor and Physical Elements in Urban Space. Proceedings of the ICA, 2, 1–8.

operation.description: Modify building configurations and skyline profiles to alter the geometric enclosure and openness characteristics of the urban canyon, affecting the visible sky hemisphere from street-level viewpoints.

pathway.mechanism_description: Changes in building shape and height distribution directly alter the Sky View Factor (SVF) by modifying the ratio of visible sky to total hemispherical view. Higher buildings or more enclosed configurations reduce SVF, creating enclosed spatial perception, while lower or fragmented skylines increase SVF, enhancing openness perception. The spatial variation in SVF across different street locations produces corresponding variations in perceived openness.

magnitude.value: descriptive: 7.68% average difference in SVF (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Nishio, S., & Ito, F. (2019). Application of Method for Calculating Sky View Factor Using Google Street View: Relation Between Sky View Factor and Physical Elements in Urban Space. Proceedings of the ICA, 2, 1–8.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of vegetation in urban areas to enhance Green View Index (GVI), creating more vegetated surfaces visible at street level and throughout the urban fabric.

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater vegetation coverage increases particulate matter filtration and deposition on leaf surfaces, while enhancing atmospheric mixing and reducing PM10 concentrations through biophysical processes including dry deposition and turbulent dispersion around vegetated areas.

source.citation: O'Regan, A. C., Byrne, R., Hellebust, S., & Nyhan, M. M. (2022). Associations between Google Street View-derived urban greenspace metrics and air pollution measured using a distributed sensor network. Sustainable Cities and Society, 87, 104221.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of urban vegetation in the middleground view layer to enhance Green View Index across street networks and public spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater vegetation coverage increases the visible green surface area from pedestrian viewpoints, which correlates positively with particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10) filtration capacity. The expanded vegetative biomass provides more leaf surface area for particle deposition and air quality improvement through biological filtration processes

source.citation: O'Regan, A. C., Byrne, R., Hellebust, S., & Nyhan, M. M. (2022). Associations between Google Street View-derived urban greenspace metrics and air pollution measured using a distributed sensor network. Sustainable Cities and Society, 87, 104221.

operation.description: Reduce building mass and vertical enclosure in the background to increase sky view factor and visual openness in urban street environments

pathway.mechanism_description: Decreased SVF (negative direction) is associated with reduced perceived liveliness/interest. Lower SVF indicates more vertical enclosure and less sky visibility, which creates a more enclosed spatial configuration that may reduce the sense of spatial drama and visual complexity that contributes to perceived liveliness. Higher building mass in the background constrains visual field and reduces environmental stimulation.

source.citation: Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

operation.description: Add vegetation elements to increase visual complexity and textural variety in the middle ground of urban streetscapes, creating diverse vertical and horizontal layering patterns

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced vegetation texture increases visual heterogeneity and spatial depth perception, stimulating visual interest and creating a more dynamic, lively environment that engages observers through varied forms, patterns, and rhythmic composition

source.citation: Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

operation.description: Modify the shape characteristics of foreground vegetation to reduce terrain ratio (vertical to horizontal proportion), creating more horizontally-oriented or low-profile vegetation arrangements in the immediate viewshed.

pathway.mechanism_description: Decreasing the terrain ratio in the foreground reduces visual complexity and vertical prominence of vegetation elements. Lower terrain ratios are associated with old-fashioned or negative aesthetic perceptions (Class 3), as they may create flatter, less dynamic spatial experiences. The negative direction indicates that lower terrain ratios correlate with decreased subjective aesthetic preference in this perceptual category.

source.citation: Ogawa, Y., Oki, T., Zhao, C., Sekimoto, Y., & Shimizu, C. (2024). Evaluating the subjective perceptions of streetscapes using street-view images. Landscape and Urban Planning, 247, 105073.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of vegetation elements in the middleground view through strategic addition of trees, shrubs, and other green infrastructure along streets and in public spaces within Copenhagen Municipality.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding vegetation coverage in the middleground visual field directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby elevating the mean Green View Index. The middleground tier is critical as it represents the primary visual engagement zone for pedestrians, where added vegetation has maximum visibility impact on GVI measurements derived from semantic segmentation of Google Street View imagery.

source.citation: Qi, L., Hu, Y., Bu, R., Xiong, Z., Li, B., Zhang, C., Liu, H., & Li, C. (2024). Spatial-temporal patterns and influencing factors of the Building Green View Index: A new approach for quantifying 3D urban greenery visibility. Sustainable Cities and Society, 111, 105518.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of vegetation elements in the foreground viewing area through strategic addition of green infrastructure including street trees, planted strips, and vegetated buffers along roadways and pedestrian zones.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding vegetation size and coverage in the foreground tier directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby elevating Green View Index measurements. Foreground vegetation has maximum visual impact due to proximity to observation points, creating immediate screening effects that enhance perceived greenness in the urban streetscape.

magnitude.value: descriptive: GVI spatial distribution patterns analyzed through semantic segmentation of Google Street View imagery (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Qi, L., Hu, Y., Bu, R., Xiong, Z., Li, B., Zhang, C., Liu, H., & Li, C. (2024). Spatial-temporal patterns and influencing factors of the Building Green View Index: A new approach for quantifying 3D urban greenery visibility. Sustainable Cities and Society, 111, 105518.

operation.description: Modify building configuration and street canyon geometry to increase sky view factor and openness in central business district streetscapes

pathway.mechanism_description: Altering building heights, setbacks, and street width ratios changes the geometric relationship between vertical surfaces and open sky, directly affecting the proportion of visible sky hemisphere measured by Sky View Factor. Wider street canyons or lower building-to-street width ratios increase angular exposure to sky dome.

source.citation: Fang, Q., Inoue, T., ZHIQIU, X., & Qiang, L. (2022). Street Sky Openness Estimation Based on Deep Learning——Case Study of Hakata Station Area, Fukuoka. Proceedings of the 58th ISOCARP World Planning Congress.

operation.description: Increase the size and quantity of vegetation elements in the foreground of street views to enhance visible green coverage

pathway.mechanism_description: Enlarging vegetation size in the foreground directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby contributing positively to the Green View Index calculation which measures the percentage of greenery visible from pedestrian perspective

source.citation: Qin, X., Yang, D., & Wangari, V. W. (2024). Quantitative characterization and evaluation of highway greening landscape spatial quality based on deep learning. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 107, 107559.

operation.description: Morph vegetation patterns in the middleground to create diverse, irregular shape configurations that enhance visual complexity while maintaining ecological connectivity across urban green spaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Morphing vegetation shapes increases visual attractiveness through enhanced landscape diversity and dynamic patterns. Irregular, organic shapes create visual interest and aesthetic appeal. At the same time, diverse vegetation configurations support ecosystem stability by providing varied habitat structures, microclimate zones, and ecological niches that strengthen biodiversity and resilience.

source.citation: Qin, X., Yang, D., & Wangari, V. W. (2024). Quantitative characterization and evaluation of highway greening landscape spatial quality based on deep learning. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 107, 107559.

operation.description: Increase the amount or coverage of vegetation elements in the foreground of street views to enhance pedestrian visual experience and perceived aesthetic quality

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater vegetation size/quantity in foreground increases green visual exposure for pedestrians, which positively influences subjective ratings of streetscape aesthetic quality through biophilic response and visual comfort enhancement

source.citation: Qiu, W., Li, W., Liu, X., & Huang, X. (2022). Subjectively Measured Streetscape Qualities for Shanghai with Large-Scale Application of Computer Vision and Machine Learning. Proceedings of the 2021 DigitalFUTURES, 242–251.

operation.description: Add natural vegetation elements to increase naturalness levels in the middle ground of urban streetscapes, creating diverse textures and natural patterns that enhance visual complexity.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher naturalness (increased vegetation texture and natural patterns) captures greater visual attention through bottom-up attentional mechanisms, resulting in more frequent visits, longer fixation durations, and increased glance counts. Natural elements provide visual novelty and biophilic stimuli that unconsciously draw viewer gaze and sustain attention.

source.citation: Qiu, Y., Pan, H., Kalantari, Z., Giusti, M., & Che, S. (2023). The natural focus: Combining deep learning and eye-tracking to understand public perceptions of urban ecosystem aesthetics. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111181.

operation.description: Modify the complexity of vegetation composition in the middleground by diversifying species mix, structural layers, and spatial arrangement patterns to create varied visual experiences and rich aesthetic qualities.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased vegetation complexity enhances ecosystem aesthetic perception through multiple pathways: (1) greater species diversity creates varied color, texture, and form combinations that stimulate visual interest; (2) multi-layered vegetation structures (canopy-understory-groundcover) provide depth and spatial richness; (3) heterogeneous spatial patterns generate visual rhythm and focal points; (4) complexity signals ecosystem health and naturalness, triggering positive psychological responses; (5) seasonal variation in complex vegetation creates dynamic aesthetic experiences throughout the year.

source.citation: Qiu, Y., Pan, H., Kalantari, Z., Giusti, M., & Che, S. (2023). The natural focus: Combining deep learning and eye-tracking to understand public perceptions of urban ecosystem aesthetics. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111181.

operation.description: Add vegetation with higher visual complexity and textural richness in the foreground of street view to increase visual interest and engagement along pedestrian pathways

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced textural complexity in foreground vegetation reduces average glance count by creating more visually engaging scenes that capture and hold attention longer, reducing the need for frequent visual scanning. Rich plant textures provide sufficient visual stimulation that decreases restless eye movement patterns associated with psychological stress

source.citation: Qiu, Y., Pan, H., Kalantari, Z., Giusti, M., & Che, S. (2023). The natural focus: Combining deep learning and eye-tracking to understand public perceptions of urban ecosystem aesthetics. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111181.

operation.description: Reduce the size and visual dominance of vegetation elements in the middle ground of street views to decrease the Road View Index (RVI) values.

pathway.mechanism_description: Decreasing vegetation size in the middleground reduces the RVI (vegetation visibility metric), which according to the negative direction relationship (DIR_NEG) leads to improved spatial quality scores. Lower vegetation dominance may enhance visual permeability and spatial openness perceived by users.

source.citation: Rui, Q., & Cheng, H. (2023). Quantifying the spatial quality of urban streets with open street view images: A case study of the main urban area of Fuzhou. Ecological Indicators, 156, 111204.

operation.description: Increase visible greenery and vegetation coverage within the visual field along walking routes to enhance Green View Index (GVI) measured through street-level imagery

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI creates more visually appealing walking environments that encourage leisure walking behavior by providing aesthetic pleasure, perceived naturalness, and psychological restoration during outdoor activities

source.citation: Sakamoto, S., Kogure, M., Hanibuchi, T., Nakaya, N., Hozawa, A., & Nakaya, T. (2023). Effects of greenery at different heights in neighbourhood streetscapes on leisure walking: A cross-sectional study using machine learning of streetscape images in Sendai City, Japan. International Journal of Health Geographics, 22(1).

operation.description: Modify the ratio of vegetation interface depth (visual depth occupied by greenery) to the total visible distance along street corridors to optimize visual engagement and spatial enclosure.

pathway.mechanism_description: Appropriate vegetation interface depth ratios create balanced visual layers that prevent both monotonous openness and excessive visual clutter. Optimal ratios establish comfortable viewing distances that align with human visual perception thresholds, reducing eye strain while maintaining adequate spatial legibility and aesthetic interest through layered green elements.

source.citation: Shao, Y., Yin, Y., Xue, Z., & Ma, D. (2023). Assessing and Comparing the Visual Comfort of Streets across Four Chinese Megacities Using AI-Based Image Analysis and the Perceptive Evaluation Method. Land, 12(4), 834.

operation.description: Modify the size and proportion of vegetation elements in the middle ground to optimize visual comfort through appropriate green view index levels in street environments.

pathway.mechanism_description: The size of vegetation in the visual field directly affects perceived visual comfort by influencing the green view index. Appropriate vegetation size in the middleground creates visual balance, reduces visual clutter, and provides psychological restoration effects. Excessive or insufficient vegetation size can negatively impact aesthetic perception and visual comfort scores.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Shenzhen mean=0.627, Guangzhou mean=0.723 (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Shao, Y., Yin, Y., Xue, Z., & Ma, D. (2023). Assessing and Comparing the Visual Comfort of Streets across Four Chinese Megacities Using AI-Based Image Analysis and the Perceptive Evaluation Method. Land, 12(4), 834.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of vegetation elements in the middle-ground visual field to enhance green view index in urban streetscapes

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding vegetation size in the middleground increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby improving aesthetic quality perception. Higher GVI correlates negatively with urbanization intensity, suggesting that aesthetic enhancement requires substantial green infrastructure investment to counterbalance built environment density

source.citation: Shen, Q., Zeng, W., Ye, Y., Arisona, S. M., Schubiger, S., Burkhard, R., & Qu, H. (2018). StreetVizor: Visual Exploration of Human-Scale Urban Forms Based on Street Views. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 24(1), 1004–1013.

operation.description: Modify the shape and configuration of vegetation elements in the middleground to enhance visual diversity and aesthetic quality of streetscape composition.

pathway.mechanism_description: Human perception of streetscape aesthetics is positively correlated with the diversity and visual interest created by vegetation forms. Varying vegetation shapes in the middleground creates visual rhythm and focal points that enhance overall perceptual quality and user experience.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Mean=3.30, SD=0.59 (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Tao, Y., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Tian, G., & Zhang, S. (2022). Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land, 11(3), 400.

operation.description: Add diverse vegetation forms and configurations in the middleground of streetscapes to enhance visual richness and perceptual quality of the street environment

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced streetscape perception through varied vegetation shapes increases environmental attractiveness and comfort, thereby drawing more pedestrians and encouraging longer duration of human activities in the street space

source.citation: Tao, Y., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Tian, G., & Zhang, S. (2022). Measuring the Correlation between Human Activity Density and Streetscape Perceptions: An Analysis Based on Baidu Street View Images in Zhengzhou, China. Land, 11(3), 400.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of overhead tree canopy in the background layer of street corridors to enhance vertical greenery visibility

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding overhead tree canopy size increases NDVI values and Green View Index by adding vegetation mass to the upper visual field, creating continuous green overhead coverage that is captured in both satellite imagery and street-level views

source.citation: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

operation.description: Add diverse vegetation types with varied structural forms (trees, shrubs, groundcovers) in different vertical layers to create heterogeneous street greenery composition in the middleground zone

pathway.mechanism_description: Incorporating multiple vegetation layers with distinct shapes and heights increases structural complexity and diversity indices by creating varied spatial arrangements, enhancing vertical stratification and habitat heterogeneity along street corridors

magnitude.value: descriptive: New City mean=0.6154, Old City mean=0.5513 (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Tong, M., She, J., Tan, J., Li, M., Ge, R., & Gao, Y. (2020). Evaluating Street Greenery by Multiple Indicators Using Street-Level Imagery and Satellite Images: A Case Study in Nanjing, China. Forests, 11(12), 1347.

operation.description: Increase the amount and size of visible vegetation elements in the foreground of the visual field to enhance green view index as perceived from eye-level human perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater foreground vegetation size directly increases the proportion of green pixels in eye-level imagery, which correlates positively with human perception of greenness. The foreground positioning maximizes visual prominence and salience of vegetation elements, leading to higher self-reported perceived greenery scores.

source.citation: Torkko, J., Poom, A., Willberg, E., & Toivonen, T. (2023). How to best map greenery from a human perspective? Comparing computational measurements with human perception. Frontiers in Sustainable Cities, 5.

operation.description: Increase the proportion and visibility of green vegetation elements in the foreground of street-level views to enhance visual greenery perception from human perspective.

pathway.mechanism_description: Foreground vegetation has stronger visual impact on perceived greenery than background elements. Increasing foreground green size directly enhances green visual index (GVI) values, which correlates with human-reported greenery perception when computational mapping accounts for depth and viewing perspective.

source.citation: Torkko, J., Poom, A., Willberg, E., & Toivonen, T. (2023). How to best map greenery from a human perspective? Comparing computational measurements with human perception. Frontiers in Sustainable Cities, 5.

operation.description: Add diverse vegetation types and textures in the middleground to increase visual variety and complexity of urban surroundings

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased diversity of vegetation textures in the middleground creates visual richness and varied spatial experiences that stimulate curiosity and encourage exploratory behavior in urban environments

source.citation: Verma, D., Jana, A., & Ramamritham, K. (2018). Quantifying Urban Surroundings Using Deep Learning Techniques: A New Proposal. Urban Science, 2(3), 78.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of natural vegetation elements in the middle ground of urban park scenes to enhance visible greenery and natural composition.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding natural vegetation size in the middleground increases the naturalness indicator (IND_NAT), which positively influences aesthetic performance (PRF_AES) by creating more appealing and nature-rich visual scenes. Greater natural elements enhance perceived attractiveness through biophilic responses and preference for natural landscapes over built environments.

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Simplify vegetation composition by reducing the diversity and complexity of plant species, structural layers, and spatial arrangements in urban green spaces to create more visually coherent and less cluttered landscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Reducing richness (diversity and complexity of park elements) decreases visual complexity and cognitive load, resulting in improved aesthetic perception. Simplified vegetation arrangements with fewer species types and structural variations create cleaner visual patterns that are easier to process and more aesthetically pleasing to viewers, as excessive diversity can lead to visual chaos and reduced preference scores.

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Add or increase shrub plantings in the middleground of urban green spaces to enhance visual enclosure and spatial intimacy.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased shrub presence in the middleground creates spatial enclosure and visual softness that may reduce perceived openness and ambient brightness, potentially inducing feelings of melancholy or introspection. The intermediate scale vegetation moderates visual prospect and creates more enclosed, contemplative settings that correlate with depressive emotional responses.

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Modify the shape and form characteristics of water features in urban green spaces to enhance visual appeal and spatial definition

pathway.mechanism_description: Modifying the shape of water features influences aesthetic perception by creating distinctive visual focal points, enhancing spatial rhythm and balance, and generating dynamic reflective surfaces that increase landscape attractiveness through improved compositional harmony and sensory engagement.

magnitude.value: descriptive: mean=31.84%, SD=14.67%, range=6.94%-64.19% (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Increase building density and height to reduce sky view factor in urban areas, creating more enclosed spatial configurations through vertical development.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher building density and taller structures reduce SVF by blocking sky visibility, which correlates with increased total population through higher residential capacity and urban density. The negative relationship indicates that lower SVF (more enclosed spaces) associates with higher population concentrations in socially active urban environments.

source.citation: Amiruzzaman, M., Zhao, Y., Amiruzzaman, S., Karpinski, A. C., & Wu, T. H. (2023). An AI-based framework for studying visual diversity of urban neighborhoods and its relationship with socio-demographic variables. Journal of Computational Social Science, 6(1), 315–337.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of vegetation elements at pedestrian eye-level (foreground) to enhance green view index visibility from ground perspective, including street trees, hedges, and vertical greenery within 0-10m viewing distance.

pathway.mechanism_description: Pedestrian-level vegetation directly occupies the visual field captured by street-view analysis, increasing GVI percentage. Higher foreground greenery creates immediate visual contact with nature, enhancing perceived abundance and satisfaction with urban greenery through increased green pixel proportion in human visual cone.

source.citation: Wang, H., & van Ameijde, J. (2023). Quantifying the Impact of Pedestrian-level Greening on the Perception of Walking. CAADRIA Proceedings, 2, 451–460.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of urban greenery (trees, shrubs, and ground vegetation) in the middle ground layer to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) visible from pedestrian viewpoints.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI improves thermal comfort by providing visual cues of coolness and shade availability, which mediates Thermal Comfort Vote (TCV) through psychological pathways. Increased visible greenery reduces perceived heat stress and enhances the subjective assessment of thermal conditions in urban microclimates.

source.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of urban greenery (trees, shrubs, and grass) in the middleground area to enhance tree view factor visibility from pedestrian viewpoints.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanded vegetation coverage increases the Tree View Factor (TVF), which mediates thermal comfort through microclimate regulation mechanisms including solar radiation interception, evapotranspiration cooling, and air temperature reduction. Higher TVF correlates with improved Thermal Comfort Vote (TCV) by creating cooler microclimatic conditions in urban spaces.

source.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

operation.description: Add vegetation layers in the middleground to reduce building visibility and create natural visual screening between viewer and built structures

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased vegetation coverage reduces Building Visibility Index by introducing natural texture that obscures hard urban surfaces, thereby lowering perceived depression scores through enhanced biophilic exposure and reduced built environment dominance in visual field

source.citation: Wang, K., Fang, X., Ma, Y., Xue, S., & Yin, S. (2022). Assessing Effects of Urban Greenery on the Regulation Mechanism of Microclimate and Outdoor Thermal Comfort during Winter in China's Cold Region. Land, 11(9), 1442.

operation.description: Infill vegetation in middle-ground urban areas through neighborhood renewal programs to enhance visual texture and environmental quality of streetscapes

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding vegetation texture in the middle-ground layer improves visual complexity and naturalness perception, which positively contributes to overall aesthetic quality scores by increasing greenery presence and visual richness in the viewing field

source.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

operation.description: Modify the physical characteristics and visual texture of building facades and urban structures in the middleground to enhance aesthetic quality based on identified contributing factors

pathway.mechanism_description: Improving the visual texture and physical attributes of buildings in the viewing field enhances visual aesthetic perception by increasing visual richness, reducing monotony, and creating more visually pleasing urban scenes that contribute positively to beauty scores

magnitude.value: descriptive: >3 points improvement in visual quality scores associated with physical environment interventions (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

operation.description: Add vegetation elements with colorful attributes in the middle ground of urban streetscapes to enhance visual richness and variety in the perceivable field of view.

pathway.mechanism_description: Colorful vegetation increases visual diversity and chromatic stimulation in street views, which enhances aesthetic perception and generates positive emotional responses associated with cheerfulness. The color variation breaks visual monotony and creates engaging visual experiences that counteract depressive perceptions.

source.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

operation.description: Reduce the size and scale of buildings in the middleground view corridor, or remove obstructive building masses that block visual access to background vegetation

pathway.mechanism_description: Building Volume Index (BVI) negatively impacts Panoramic View Green View Index (PVGVI) by occupying visual field space that could otherwise display vegetation. Reducing building size in the middleground opens up sight lines, allowing more background greenery to be visible in panoramic views, thereby increasing the proportion of green elements captured in the visual assessment

source.citation: Wang, M., Haworth, J., Chen, H., Liu, Y., & Shi, Z. (2024). Investigating the potential of crowdsourced street-level imagery in understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of cities: A case study of walkability in Inner London. Cities, 153, 105243.

operation.description: Increase the size and quantity of street-level vegetation (trees, shrubs, and greenery) along urban streets to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) in the foreground visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI from increased street greening leads to improved air quality by reducing AQI and PM10 levels through vegetation's capacity to capture particulate matter, absorb pollutants, and create physical barriers that filter air pollutants at street level where human exposure occurs.

source.citation: Wu, D., Gong, J., Liang, J., Sun, J., & Zhang, G. (2020). Analyzing the Influence of Urban Street Greening and Street Buildings on Summertime Air Pollution Based on Street View Image Data. ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information, 9(9), 500.

operation.description: Increase tree view factor (TVF) in courtyard spaces by adding vegetation elements that enhance visual canopy coverage from occupant viewpoints

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher tree view factor provides increased perceived shade coverage and psychological cooling effect, reducing the frequency of thermal heat discomfort through combined physiological and psychological pathways in courtyard microclimates

source.citation: Wu, R., Fang, X., Brown, R., Liu, S., & Zhao, H. (2023). Establishing a link between complex courtyard spaces and thermal comfort: A major advancement in evidence-based design. Building and Environment, 245, 110852.

operation.description: Increase the size and density of vegetation elements in the foreground of street spaces, particularly at eye-level and within immediate visual proximity to pedestrians in Nanjing urban streets.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding foreground vegetation coverage directly increases the Green View Index (GVI) by occupying a larger proportion of the visual field captured from pedestrian viewpoints. Street-level greenery in the foreground has the most significant impact on perceived greenery exposure due to its proximity and visual dominance in the observer's field of view.

source.citation: Wu, Z., Xu, K., Li, Y., Zhao, X., & Qian, Y. (2024). Application of an Integrated Model for Analyzing Street Greenery through Image Semantic Segmentation and Accessibility: A Case Study of Nanjing City. Forests, 15(3), 561.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of green vegetation in the foreground view to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) within the urban visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI improves visual perception of urban space quality by increasing the proportion of natural elements in the viewshed, creating a more pleasant and restorative visual environment that positively affects aesthetic experience and psychological well-being.

magnitude.value: descriptive: GVI calculation formula (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Liu, W., Hu, X., Song, Z., & Yuan, X. (2023). Identifying the integrated visual characteristics of greenway landscape: A focus on human perception. Sustainable Cities and Society, 99, 104937.

operation.description: Reduce the visual coverage of green vegetation in the middle ground of street views to decrease overall greenery density and visibility

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower Green View Index (GVI) reduces visual screening and natural surveillance opportunities, creating less defined territorial boundaries and potentially increasing perceived vulnerability. Reduced vegetation coverage may expose more undefined spaces and decrease environmental legibility, leading to lower perceived safety scores

source.citation: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., Ren, S., Zhang, J., Song, X., & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents' psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

operation.description: Modify the visual texture and structural complexity of trees in the foreground to enhance visibility and visual richness of street tree canopies

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased visual texture through diverse canopy structures, leaf patterns, and branching complexity creates dynamic visual interest that enhances perceived liveliness. Visually rich tree forms with varied textures capture attention and contribute to a more animated streetscape perception, improving aesthetic performance through biological diversity and structural variation

source.citation: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., Ren, S., Zhang, J., Song, X., & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents' psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

operation.description: Reduce the size or density of middleground vegetation to decrease visual enclosure in the streetscape

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower Green View Index creates less spatial enclosure, which indirectly reduces aesthetic preference by diminishing the sense of shelter and definition in the visual field. The negative relationship operates through the mediating factor of enclosure perception.

source.citation: Dai, L., Zheng, C., Dong, Z., Yao, Y., Wang, R., Zhang, X., Ren, S., Zhang, J., Song, X., & Guan, Q. (2021). Analyzing the correlation between visual space and residents' psychology in Wuhan, China using street-view images and deep-learning technique. City and Environment Interactions, 11, 100069.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of vegetation across urban neighborhoods to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) at the background/district scale.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI reduces mortality risk during extreme heat by lowering surface temperatures through evapotranspiration and shading, improving thermal comfort, and mitigating urban heat island effects. Enhanced vegetation coverage provides passive cooling that protects vulnerable populations during heat waves.

source.citation: Song, J., Zhu, X., & Yu, X. (2023). Monitoring and mapping vegetation greenery in residential communities using street view images and a Normalized Vegetation Greenery Index: A case study in Beijing, China. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 6.

operation.description: Increase the size and quantity of vegetation elements in the foreground view to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) within the immediate visual field of observers

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI values achieved through increased foreground vegetation coverage directly improve visual comfort by introducing natural elements into the viewshed, which enhances greenery perception through greater proportional representation of green surfaces in street-level panoramic views. The psychological restorative effect of visible nature creates positive aesthetic experiences and reduces visual stress

source.citation: Xiao, C., Shi, Q., & Gu, C.-J. (2021). Assessing the Spatial Distribution Pattern of Street Greenery and Its Relationship with Socioeconomic Status and the Built Environment in Shanghai, China. Land, 10(8), 871.

operation.description: Optimize the spatial configuration and shape patterns of background green spaces to achieve more equitable distribution of green view index across different urban areas, morphing fragmented or irregularly shaped green patches into more cohesive and strategically positioned configurations that enhance visual accessibility citywide.

pathway.mechanism_description: Reshaping background landscape patterns of green spaces (morphing their spatial configuration) directly influences the spatial fairness of green view availability by reducing inequality in GVI distribution. Better-configured spatial patterns ensure more equitable visual access to greenery across socioeconomically diverse neighborhoods, thereby decreasing spatial disparities (negative relationship with inequality).

source.citation: Xiao, L., Wang, W., Ren, Z., Wei, C., & He, X. (2024). Landscape Patterns of Green Spaces Drive the Availability and Spatial Fairness of Street Greenery in Changchun City, Northeastern China. Forests, 15(7), 1074.

operation.description: Optimize the spatial configuration and pattern complexity of green space networks at the neighborhood/district scale to create more regular and aggregated green space distributions that enhance equitable visibility across different urban areas.

pathway.mechanism_description: Morphing green space patterns from fragmented to aggregated configurations reduces spatial inequality in Green View Index (GVI) distribution. More regular landscape patterns (lower shape complexity) and clustered green space arrangements ensure more consistent and equitable street-level greenery exposure across socioeconomically diverse neighborhoods, thereby decreasing GVI inequality metrics.

source.citation: Xiao, L., Wang, W., Ren, Z., Wei, C., & He, X. (2024). Landscape Patterns of Green Spaces Drive the Availability and Spatial Fairness of Street Greenery in Changchun City, Northeastern China. Forests, 15(7), 1074.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of vegetation elements in the middleground visual field to achieve higher Green View Index (GVI) threshold levels in urban streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation coverage (measured by GVI threshold performance) reduces perceived thermal discomfort by providing visual cooling cues, shading psychological effects, and associations with cooler microclimates. The increased green visibility in the middleground viewing range creates stronger perceptual thermal comfort responses, thereby positively influencing the Discomfort Index.

source.citation: Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of vegetation in the middle ground view to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) within the urban visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI through increased vegetation coverage reduces negative emotional states (sad facial expressions) by providing visual access to nature, which triggers psychological restoration, stress reduction, and positive affective responses through biophilic mechanisms.

source.citation: Xin, B., Zhu, C., Geng, J., & Liu, Y. (2024). Emotional Perceptions of Thermal Comfort for People Exposed to Green Spaces Characterized Using Streetscapes in Urban Parks. Land, 13(9), 1515.

operation.description: Modify building height, mass, and spatial configuration to control the proportion of visible sky hemisphere in urban canyon spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Building geometry directly determines the occlusion angle of the sky dome from ground-level viewpoints. Reduced building heights, increased setbacks, or optimized building arrangement increases the visible sky portion, thereby raising SVF values. The SVF range (likely 0-1 scale) in Qinhuai District reflects varying degrees of sky obstruction by built form across different urban morphologies

magnitude.value: descriptive: SVF range 0.15-0.85 in Qinhuai District (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Xu, H., Lu, H., & Liu, S. (2024). Online Street View-Based Approach for Sky View Factor Estimation: A Case Study of Nanjing, China. Applied Sciences, 14(5), 2133.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of street-level vegetation through strategic addition of greenery elements along urban corridors to enhance the Green View Index distribution pattern.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding the size of foreground vegetation directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-view imagery, thereby elevating the Green View Index (GVI) and improving aesthetic perception through enhanced visual exposure to natural elements at pedestrian eye-level.

source.citation: Xue, C., Jin, C., Zhou, L., & Li, G. (2022). Exploring the distribution of city street greenery from eye-level: An application of Baidu Map panoramic images data. Geografisk Tidsskrift-Danish Journal of Geography, 122(1), 73–86.

operation.description: Increase the amount of street greenery visible and accessible from residential blocks through strategic addition of vegetation along streetscapes within daily access range of private neighborhoods.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced daily accessed street greenery increases property values by improving environmental quality, aesthetic appeal, and perceived neighborhood desirability. The visibility and accessibility of green infrastructure creates amenity value that is capitalized into housing prices, as residents value proximity to and views of vegetated streetscapes in their daily living environment.

source.citation: Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.

operation.description: Modify building height and configuration to increase sky view factor in urban streetscapes, allowing more open sky visibility from ground level viewing positions.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased SVF enhances visual openness and spatial perception by expanding the visible sky dome, reducing visual enclosure from built environment, and improving the sense of spaciousness which positively contributes to visual quality assessment scores.

source.citation: Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.

operation.description: Add vegetation along street walkways to enhance textural variety and visual richness in the pedestrian environment, creating layered visual experiences through diverse plant forms and patterns.

pathway.mechanism_description: Vegetation texture along walkways increases visual complexity and naturalistic elements in the streetscape, which enhances aesthetic perception and visual quality scores by providing multi-sensory engagement and breaking up monotonous urban hardscapes.

source.citation: Ye, Y., Zeng, W., Shen, Q., Zhang, X., & Lu, Y. (2019). The visual quality of streets: A human-centred continuous measurement based on machine learning algorithms and street view images. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 46(8), 1439–1457.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of urban greenspace vegetation in residential neighborhoods and community areas accessible to older adults, enhancing the overall size and extent of vegetated areas within the urban fabric.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced vegetation coverage provides increased opportunities for nature contact, physical activity, and social interaction among older adults. Greater greenspace size allows for diverse recreational activities, stress reduction through nature exposure, and improved environmental quality (air quality, noise buffering), collectively contributing to improved mental wellbeing and psychological health outcomes.

source.citation: Yue, Y., Yang, D., & Van Dyck, D. (2022). Urban greenspace and mental health in Chinese older adults: Associations across different greenspace measures and mediating effects of environmental perceptions. Health & Place, 76, 102856.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of vegetation in the middle-ground visual field to enhance green view index (GVI) within the typical viewing range of older adults in urban settings.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI creates more visible greenery in the middle-ground visual field, which may provide psychological benefits through nature exposure, though this study found no significant relationship with mental wellbeing scores in Chinese older adults, suggesting other mediating factors or contextual variables may influence the green space-mental health relationship.

source.citation: Yue, Y., Yang, D., & Van Dyck, D. (2022). Urban greenspace and mental health in Chinese older adults: Associations across different greenspace measures and mediating effects of environmental perceptions. Health & Place, 76, 102856.

operation.description: Modify tree crown shape to optimize shading coverage on road surfaces through selective pruning or species selection that promotes specific canopy geometries (e.g., spreading vs. columnar forms).

pathway.mechanism_description: Tree shape determines the spatial distribution and quality of shade cast on road surfaces. Broader, more horizontal crown shapes increase shade area and duration on pavement, reducing direct solar radiation absorption and consequently lowering road surface temperatures through decreased thermal loading.

source.citation: Zeng, L., Lindberg, F., Zhang, X., Pan, H., & Lu, J. (2023). Road surface temperature evaluated with streetview-derived parameters in a hot and humid megacity. Urban Climate, 51, 101585.

operation.description: Increase street tree canopy coverage by adding more trees or selecting larger species to enhance the sky view obstruction (reduce Building View Index) along road corridors.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced tree canopy size increases shading coverage on road surfaces, directly blocking solar radiation during peak hours. The reduced BVI (threshold-based performance) indicates sufficient overhead canopy density to intercept shortwave radiation, thereby lowering daily maximum road surface temperatures through reduced heat absorption and enhanced evapotranspiration cooling.

source.citation: Zeng, L., Lindberg, F., Zhang, X., Pan, H., & Lu, J. (2023). Road surface temperature evaluated with streetview-derived parameters in a hot and humid megacity. Urban Climate, 51, 101585.

operation.description: Add vegetation elements in the foreground to modify the shape and visual composition of urban streetscapes

pathway.mechanism_description: Vegetation in the foreground enhances perceived safety by creating natural surveillance opportunities, softening harsh urban edges, and increasing the sense of care and maintenance. The visual presence of greenery signals active management and reduces perceptions of abandonment, thereby improving the Landsense Safety Index through enhanced environmental legibility and territorial definition

source.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

operation.description: Reduce the size and scale of buildings in the middleground to decrease their visual dominance and perceived wealth impression in urban scenes

pathway.mechanism_description: Smaller building sizes reduce the perceived opulence and affluence of urban environments. Lower building-to-sky ratio diminishes the sense of material prosperity and decreases the 'wealthy' dimension of the Landsense Index by creating a less imposing, less luxurious visual character

source.citation: Zhang, Y., Li, S., Dong, R., Deng, H., Fu, X., Wang, C., Yu, T., Jia, T., & Zhao, J. (2021). Quantifying physical and psychological perceptions of urban scenes using deep learning. Land Use Policy, 111, 105762.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of street vegetation within 200m-1km buffer zones around residential areas to enhance Green View Index (GVI) along streetscapes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation coverage increases visual exposure to greenery, which reduces stress and provides psychological restoration, thereby decreasing psychiatric disorder hospitalization rates among residents.

source.citation: Zhang, A., Zhai, S., Liu, X., Song, G., & Feng, Y. (2022). Investigating the Association between Streetscapes and Mental Health in Zhanjiang, China: Using Baidu Street View Images and Deep Learning. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 19(24), 16634.

operation.description: Reduce the size or extent of vegetation elements in the foreground to decrease visual density and increase perceived openness in urban green spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Decreasing vegetation size in the foreground reduces visual obstruction and spatial enclosure, thereby increasing the perceived spaciousness and ease of movement. This reduction in spatial definition (SPD) creates a more open visual field, enhancing the subjective perception of freedom and reducing feelings of confinement, which positively impacts aesthetic performance through improved spatial quality ratings

source.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

operation.description: Modify building height and configuration in the background to increase sky view factor, creating more open visual space and reducing visual enclosure from built structures

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher sky view factor (SVF) increases the proportion of visible sky from observation points, creating a sense of openness and spatial freedom. This reduces the oppressive feeling from tall buildings and enhances perceived landscape quality by improving visual comfort and aesthetic preference through better sky exposure

source.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

operation.description: Add vegetation to increase visible greenery ratio (RVI) in the middleground view range, creating higher proportion of natural elements within the visual field.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased vegetation visibility (RVI) leads to enhanced physiological stress response indicated by elevated skin conductance level (SCL). Higher green view ratio stimulates autonomic nervous system activation, resulting in increased electrodermal activity as measured through standardized SCL values.

source.citation: Cai, M., Xiang, L., & Ng, E. (2023). How does the visual environment influence pedestrian physiological stress? Evidence from high-density cities using ambulatory technology and spatial machine learning. Sustainable Cities and Society, 96, 104695.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of vegetation in the middle-ground view to improve Green View Index (GVI) threshold performance at the street level and neighborhood scale.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI values reduce average monthly temperature differences (Max-Min) by increasing evapotranspiration, providing continuous shade coverage, and moderating diurnal temperature fluctuations through enhanced thermal mass and moisture regulation.

source.citation: Chan, T.-C., Lee, P.-H., Lee, Y.-T., & Tang, J.-H. (2024). Exploring the spatial association between the distribution of temperature and urban morphology with green view index. PLOS ONE, 19(5), e0301921.

operation.description: Increase the amount and density of eye-level vegetation (street trees, shrubs, vertical greening) along roadways and bicycle paths to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) visible from cyclist perspective at 1.5-2m height.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced eye-level greenery creates more pleasant and attractive cycling environments, reducing psychological stress and improving aesthetic experience. Visual contact with vegetation during cycling enhances perceived comfort and safety, encouraging more frequent use of dock-less shared bicycle services in neighborhoods with higher GVI. The foreground vegetation acts as a direct visual amenity that positively influences route choice and cycling behavior.

source.citation: Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

operation.description: Increase eye-level greenery coverage along streets and pathways by adding vegetation elements in the foreground visual field, expanding the visible green infrastructure that bicycle users directly perceive during their trips.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced eye-level greenery (measured by GVI - Green View Index) creates more pleasant and attractive visual environments for cyclists, increasing the aesthetic quality and perceived safety of bicycle routes, thereby encouraging higher shared bicycle usage rates and departure densities from dock-less bicycle sharing stations.

source.citation: Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

operation.description: Reduce textural diversity and complexity of vegetation composition in the middleground by limiting species variety and creating more homogeneous planting patterns

pathway.mechanism_description: Decreasing vegetation diversity reduces visual texture variation and compositional complexity, which leads to lower aesthetic quality and reduced landscape preference as uniform vegetation patterns diminish visual interest and perceptual richness

source.citation: Zhang, X., Lin, E. S., Tan, P. Y., Qi, J., & Waykool, R. (2023). Assessment of visual landscape quality of urban green spaces using image-based metrics derived from perceived sensory dimensions. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, 102, 107200.

operation.description: Add water features of sufficient size in the middleground of urban green spaces to enhance visual presence and accessibility for users.

pathway.mechanism_description: Water features in the middleground create focal visual elements that capture attention and provide psychological restoration through fascination and stress reduction. The size of water features directly influences their perceptual salience and restorative effect, with larger water bodies offering greater visual impact, ambient sound benefits, and opportunities for contemplation. The middleground placement ensures optimal visual engagement while maintaining accessibility for multi-sensory experience.

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Reduce variation in green view index by standardizing vegetation texture and visual complexity across the middle ground of street scenes to create more uniform green visual patterns.

pathway.mechanism_description: High variation in green view index creates visual inconsistency and unpredictability in the streetscape, which may increase cognitive load and reduce the calming, restorative qualities associated with coherent natural environments. Lower GVI variation promotes visual harmony and perceptual fluency, enhancing psychological restoration through consistent nature exposure.

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Modify the position and alignment of riverfront road to optimize water view accessibility and visual corridors toward water bodies.

pathway.mechanism_description: Repositioning the riverfront road enhances visual connections between users and water features, increasing the mean Water View Index by improving sight lines and reducing visual obstructions to the waterfront, thereby enhancing aesthetic experience through better water visibility.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Mean Water View Index on Riverfront Road = 0.05 (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Increase street-level green vegetation coverage along pedestrian routes to urban parks to enhance visual exposure to greenery and create greener streetscapes with higher Green View Index (GVI) values.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher street-level vegetation texture in the middleground creates psychologically safe and attractive walking environments during health crises. The visual presence of greenery along park access routes reduces perceived COVID-19 transmission risk in outdoor spaces, increases comfort levels for outdoor activities, and enhances the perceived restorative benefits of visiting parks. This green visual corridor effect motivates people to overcome risk aversion and increases the probability of park visitation even under high pandemic risk conditions.

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Improve walkability index of street-scale environments surrounding urban parks by enhancing pedestrian infrastructure quality, connectivity, and accessibility features that facilitate safe and comfortable walking experiences.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced walkability creates safer, more accessible street environments that reduce perceived barriers to park visitation. Improved pedestrian infrastructure increases comfort and confidence in walking to parks, maintaining visitation willingness even under COVID-19 risk conditions (GLR1-GLR5) by supporting social distancing and outdoor movement patterns.

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Increase vegetation coverage along streets leading to urban parks to enhance perceived safety and visual appeal of approach routes

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced street-scale vegetation creates safer, more attractive pathways that increase willingness to visit parks even under pandemic conditions (GLR1-GLR5) by improving wayfinding comfort, reducing perceived exposure risk through natural screening, and signaling well-maintained public spaces

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Modify vegetation texture and pattern complexity in the middleground to influence visual perception and landscape compositional richness

pathway.mechanism_description: Crown projection ratio (CPR) serves as a quantifiable texture metric that captures vegetation canopy density patterns. Higher CPR values indicate greater crown coverage and textural complexity, which positively contributes to the Support Vector Machine model's prediction of visual complexity. The texture variation created by overlapping and adjacent tree crowns generates visual interest and perceptual depth, enhancing aesthetic experience through increased pattern diversity in the visual field.

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Modify the shape configuration and spatial arrangement of vegetation elements in the middleground to enhance green view index and canopy coverage metrics that contribute to visual complexity prediction.

pathway.mechanism_description: Green rate and canopy coverage (IND_GRC_CON) serve as reliable predictors of visual complexity by quantifying vegetation density and spatial distribution patterns. Modifying vegetation shape configurations increases edge diversity, fractal dimensions, and visual layering, which enhances aesthetic perception through greater visual interest and perceived naturalness in urban green spaces.

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Modify the visual texture and composition of vegetation elements in the foreground to enhance walkability perception through improved visual quality and spatial definition.

pathway.mechanism_description: Visual texture modifications of foreground vegetation affect pedestrians' perception of walkability by creating more legible and inviting walking environments. Enhanced textural quality of greenery provides visual interest, improves wayfinding cues, and contributes to perceived safety and comfort, thereby positively influencing walkability assessment through visual impact pathways.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Table 2 presents walkability index values for machine learning model validation (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of visible vegetation elements in the middle-ground viewing zone to enhance green view index (GVI) levels within urban street corridors and public spaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI values, achieved through increased vegetative coverage in the viewer's primary sight line, directly correlate with enhanced visual preference and perceived aesthetic beauty. The presence of green elements in the middle-ground creates a balanced visual composition that reduces harsh urban elements while providing natural focal points, leading to improved psychological response and aesthetic satisfaction among observers.

source.citation: Zhao, X., Lu, Y., & Lin, G. (2024). An integrated deep learning approach for assessing the visual qualities of built environments utilizing street view images. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 130, 107805.

operation.description: Modify vegetation texture and density to alter brightness and reflectance characteristics in the foreground visual field, adjusting the perceived luminance and contrast of vegetated surfaces.

pathway.mechanism_description: Changes in vegetation texture (leaf density, surface roughness, canopy structure) directly affect light reflection and absorption properties, influencing brightness perception (IND_BRT) and subsequently thermal sensation (PRF_THR). Denser, rougher textures typically reduce brightness through increased light absorption and shadow casting, correlating with cooler thermal perception ratings.

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Reduce the size and coverage of vegetation in the foreground to decrease Green View Index (GVI) percentage in the visual field

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower GVI reduces the amount of vegetation blocking sky and built surfaces, allowing more light penetration and increasing perceived brightness. Less foliage coverage decreases shadow casting and light absorption, resulting in higher luminance levels perceived by viewers

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Increase vegetation texture complexity by adding diverse plant species with varied leaf patterns, growth forms, and structural characteristics in the middleground viewing zone to enhance visual plant richness.

pathway.mechanism_description: Greater vegetation texture complexity created by diverse plant forms increases the visual detection of different species, which enhances observers' perceived plant richness. The varied patterns and structures provide visual cues that signal biodiversity, directly improving aesthetic perception through the Green View Index.

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Modify the shape and configuration of background buildings to increase sky view factor (SVF) in urban spaces by adjusting building heights, setbacks, and spatial arrangements to open up more visible sky area from ground level.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increased SVF enhances psychological well-being by providing greater visual access to sky and daylight, reducing spatial enclosure perception, improving sense of openness, and creating more comfortable microclimate conditions through better natural light penetration and air circulation, which collectively contribute to improved WHO-5 Well-being Index scores.

source.citation: Zheng, Y., Lan, S., Zhao, J., Liu, Y., He, S., & Liu, C. (2024). Modeling the Effect of Greenways' Multilevel Visual Characteristics on Thermal Perception in Summer Based on Bayesian Network and Computer Vision. Land, 13(11), 1796.

operation.description: Reduce the size and coverage of green vegetation in the middleground view to decrease Green View Index (GVI) levels in urban streetscapes and public spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Decreased GVI through reduced vegetation size/coverage in the middleground leads to negative psychological outcomes by diminishing visual contact with nature, reducing stress recovery opportunities, and lowering perceived environmental quality, thereby decreasing WHO-5 Well-being Index scores
