operation.description: Increase green view index (GVI) by adding vegetation elements in the middleground visual field to enhance textural density and coverage of greenery within urban streetscapes

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI increases evapotranspiration cooling, provides shading effects, and reduces solar radiation absorption by built surfaces, thereby lowering air temperature in urban environments through enhanced thermal regulation capacity

source.citation: Zhou, H., Tao, G., Yan, X., & Sun, J. (2021). Influences of greening and structures on urban thermal environments: A case study in Xuzhou City, China. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 66, 127386.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of vegetation elements in the middle-ground view to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) within the urban streetscape.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher vegetation coverage increases plant transpiration rates, releasing more water vapor into the surrounding air. This evapotranspiration process elevates absolute humidity levels (H) in the microclimate, as more moisture is added to the atmospheric boundary layer through biological processes.

magnitude.value: descriptive: GVI showed positive correlation with absolute humidity in spatial distribution analysis (Fig 6a visual comparison) (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhou, H., Tao, G., Yan, X., & Sun, J. (2021). Influences of greening and structures on urban thermal environments: A case study in Xuzhou City, China. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 66, 127386.

operation.description: Modify walkway shape and spatial configuration to influence pedestrian trajectory patterns and movement behavior in urban green spaces

pathway.mechanism_description: Walkway shape modifications alter pedestrian movement trajectories, which exhibit gender-differentiated patterns in visual engagement and spatial exploration. Modified path configurations create distinct behavioral signatures that correlate with visual attention allocation and aesthetic appreciation

magnitude.value: descriptive: Male trajectories distinguished by higher walking speed (mean 1.2 m/s vs 1.0 m/s) and larger spatial coverage; Female trajectories showed more frequent stops and shorter viewing distances. Gender prediction accuracy: 78.3% (proxy from linked Evidence)

operation.description: Modify walkway network configuration to optimize pedestrian accessibility and connectivity based on walkability index parameters

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced walkway positioning and network connectivity increases pedestrian route options and accessibility, thereby increasing running trajectory density as runners utilize more diverse and accessible paths throughout the urban environment

magnitude.value: descriptive: Table 2 provides running trajectory density values across different walkability index levels (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

operation.description: Increase the size and quantity of vegetation in the foreground to reduce building visibility dominance and enhance green visual continuum in the urban streetscape.

pathway.mechanism_description: Larger foreground vegetation creates visual screening that reduces the perceived dominance of building structures in the visual field, thereby increasing the green view index (BVI) by shifting the visual composition from built to natural elements. The foreground tier has the strongest visual impact on observer perception due to proximity and angular coverage.

source.citation: Stancato, G. (2024). The Visual Greenery Field: Representing the Urban Green Visual Continuum with Street View Image Analysis. Sustainability, 16(21), 9512.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of vegetation in the middleground view to enhance Green View Index (GVI) levels in street environments.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI increases visual exposure to natural green elements, which reduces visual monotony, provides biophilic stimulation, and creates positive psychological responses leading to improved visual comfort as measured by semantic differential scales.

source.citation: Sun, D., Ji, X., Gao, W., Zhou, F., Yu, Y., Meng, Y., Yang, M., Lin, J., & Lyu, M. (2023). The Relation between Green Visual Index and Visual Comfort in Qingdao Coastal Streets. Buildings, 13(2), 457.

operation.description: Modify the proportion and extent of visible vegetation in the foreground to achieve optimal Green View Index levels that balance greenness with visual openness, avoiding excessive green coverage that may cause visual oppression.

pathway.mechanism_description: Green View Index exhibits a non-linear relationship with visual comfort in aesthetic performance. Moderate GVI levels enhance visual comfort by providing natural elements and psychological restoration. However, excessive vegetation coverage can reduce visual openness and create feelings of enclosure or oppression, thereby diminishing visual comfort. The optimal GVI range balances biophilic benefits with spatial openness.

source.citation: Sun, D., Ji, X., Gao, W., Zhou, F., Yu, Y., Meng, Y., Yang, M., Lin, J., & Lyu, M. (2023). The Relation between Green Visual Index and Visual Comfort in Qingdao Coastal Streets. Buildings, 13(2), 457.

operation.description: Increase the size and quantity of vegetation elements in the foreground view plane to enhance green visibility from street-level perspectives

pathway.mechanism_description: Adding more vegetation in foreground areas directly increases the proportion of green pixels captured in street-level imagery, thereby improving the Green View Index (GVI) which measures visible greenery from human eye-level. The spatial distribution analysis shows that foreground vegetation has the strongest impact on GVI scores due to proximity to observation points

source.citation: Chen, J., Zhou, C., & Li, F. (2020). Quantifying the green view indicator for assessing urban greening quality: An analysis based on Internet-crawling street view data. Ecological Indicators, 113, 106192.

operation.description: Modify the texture and visual complexity of vegetation in the middleground of urban street environments to enhance spatial quality perception through balanced greenery distribution and visual richness.

pathway.mechanism_description: Enhanced vegetation texture in the middleground creates visual interest and spatial depth that positively influences aesthetic quality perception. The varied textures of vegetation layers (trees, shrubs) contribute to Street Spatial Quality Score by improving visual complexity, naturalness, and human-scale enclosure, which are key components of aesthetic performance in street environments.

magnitude.value: GVI: 1.507; VEI: 7.798; MVI: -2.412 (proxy from linked Evidence)

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of visible vegetation elements in the foreground of street-level views through strategic addition of trees, shrubs, and other green elements along roadways and pedestrian pathways.

pathway.mechanism_description: Expanding the proportion of vegetation visible from street level directly increases Green View Index (GVI) values by maximizing green pixels captured in horizontal field-of-view imagery. Foreground vegetation has the strongest visual impact on street view exposure measures and demonstrates positive correlation with both satellite-derived NDVI and ground-level green space metrics, validating GVI as an effective complement to traditional overhead assessment methods.

source.citation: Larkin, A., & Hystad, P. (2019). Evaluating street view exposure measures of visible green space for health research. Journal of Exposure Science & Environmental Epidemiology, 29(4), 447–456.

operation.description: Modify the size, height, and spatial configuration of buildings to reduce Sky View Factor (SVF) in urban areas, creating more enclosed street canyons and increasing the building-to-sky ratio.

pathway.mechanism_description: Reducing SVF through larger/taller building configurations decreases the visible sky hemisphere from ground level, which limits longwave radiation exchange and solar radiation exposure during daytime, thereby increasing Land Surface Temperature (LST). The positive direction indicates that lower SVF (more enclosure) correlates with higher thermal retention and elevated surface temperatures.

source.citation: Song, J., Zhu, X., & Yu, X. (2023). Monitoring and mapping vegetation greenery in residential communities using street view images and a Normalized Vegetation Greenery Index: A case study in Beijing, China. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 6.

operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of visible vegetation in the foreground and immediate viewing field to enhance green view index (GVI) at eye level, creating more vegetated surfaces within the primary visual cone of streetscape observers.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI achieved through increased foreground vegetation coverage enhances perceived relaxation by providing greater exposure to natural elements within the immediate visual field. The presence of vegetation at eye level triggers restorative psychological responses, reduces visual stress, and creates a calming environmental atmosphere that directly improves relaxation perception scores.

magnitude.value: descriptive: Mean scores across GVI levels shown in Figure 10B (proxy from linked Evidence)

source.citation: Zhang, S., Lu, J., Guo, R., & Yang, Y. (2024). Exploring the Relationship Between Visual Perception of the Urban Riverfront Core Landscape Area and the Vitality of Riverfront Road: A Case Study of Guangzhou. Land, 13(12), 2142.

operation.description: Increase the green view index (GVI) by adding visible vegetation elements in the foreground layer of urban streets to enhance visual green coverage within pedestrian sightlines.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI creates more familiar and naturalistic street environments that pedestrians perceive as safer. The presence of visible greenery in the immediate visual field increases environmental legibility, provides visual cues of maintained spaces, and reduces perceived isolation, thereby enhancing both safety perception and sense of familiarity in urban settings.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI in the middleground creates visually comfortable and natural environments that encourage people to stay longer in public spaces. The increased vegetation provides visual interest, shade, and biophilic connections that enhance behavioral responses related to staying behavior and spatial attachment.

operation.description: Increase the quantity and coverage of green vegetation in the middle-ground visual field to enhance the Green View Index (GVI) within urban street environments and residential viewing perspectives.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI exposure increases visual contact with natural green elements, which triggers psychological restoration processes through attention recovery and stress reduction mechanisms. The enhanced green visibility in the middle-ground viewing range provides sustained visual engagement with nature, leading to improved mental health outcomes as measured by GHQ-12 scores.

operation.description: Add tree canopy elements in the foreground to reduce sky view factor in pedestrian zones, creating overhead shading structures that block direct sky exposure while maintaining visual permeability at eye level.

pathway.mechanism_description: Trees with spreading canopy forms reduce SVF by occluding portions of the hemispherical sky dome visible from ground level. Lower SVF values decrease shortwave and longwave radiation exchange between ground surfaces and the sky vault, reducing radiative heat gain and thereby improving thermal comfort as reflected in thermal sensation votes.

operation.description: Increase the size and coverage of vegetation elements in the foreground view to enhance Green View Index (GVI) values in street-level perspectives.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher GVI represents greater visible greenery in the visual field. However, the study found no significant relationship between GVI and thermal sensation vote, suggesting that visual greenery alone does not necessarily translate to thermal comfort improvement without considering actual shading effectiveness and microclimate modification.

source.citation: Chiang, Y.-C., Liu, H.-H., Li, D., & Ho, L.-C. (2023). Quantification through deep learning of sky view factor and greenery on urban streets during hot and cool seasons. Landscape and Urban Planning, 232, 104679.

pathway.mechanism_description: Increasing tree canopy size and coverage directly obstructs the visible sky hemisphere, thereby reducing SVF values. operation.description: Increase the amount and coverage of visible vegetation elements in the foreground view along pedestrian routes, including trees, shrubs, and other greenery that contribute to green view index measurements at eye level.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher green view index (GVI) is negatively associated with pedestrian trip numbers, suggesting that excessive foreground vegetation may create visual barriers, reduce wayfinding clarity, obstruct sight lines to destinations and amenities, or create perceived safety concerns that discourage walking activity. The negative correlation indicates that while greenery provides aesthetic benefits, over-greening in the immediate visual field may impede pedestrian movement patterns captured through smartphone trajectory data.

operation.description: Modify building enclosure patterns by reshaping the spatial configuration and form complexity of built structures in the background urban fabric to reduce visual and physical barriers.

pathway.mechanism_description: Higher building enclosure (measured by IND_ENC_BLD) creates stronger spatial containment and barriers that restrict pedestrian movement flow and reduce trip generation. Morphing building shapes to reduce enclosure improves spatial permeability, enhances visual connectivity, and facilitates pedestrian navigation, thereby increasing pedestrian trip numbers through improved walkability and reduced psychological barriers to movement.

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

operation.description: Modify building enclosure configurations by reshaping the built form arrangements and spatial enclosure patterns along pedestrian pathways to create varied spatial sequences and enclosure ratios.

pathway.mechanism_description: Building enclosure shapes that create well-defined spatial boundaries and varied enclosure degrees enhance pedestrian comfort and spatial legibility, encouraging walking behavior. The morphological configuration of building masses generates enclosure effects that provide shelter, sense of protection, and visual interest, positively influencing pedestrian trip generation.

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

operation.description: Reduce the size and coverage of street-level vegetation in the foreground visual field to decrease the Green View Index (GVI) along pedestrian routes.

pathway.mechanism_description: Lower GVI values (reduced visible greenery) correlate with decreased pedestrian trip numbers, suggesting that less visual exposure to vegetation may diminish the attractiveness and comfort of walking environments, thereby reducing pedestrian activity. The negative relationship indicates that minimizing green visual presence discourages walking behavior.

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

operation.description: Add trees along pedestrian walkways and street edges to create tree-lined corridors that enhance the walking environment and provide visual continuity in the foreground spatial layer.

pathway.mechanism_description: Tree canopy creates shaded, comfortable microclimates that encourage pedestrian activity. The vertical structure and rhythmic placement of trees along walkways improves visual interest and wayfinding, while providing psychological comfort through natural enclosure. Enhanced aesthetic quality and thermal comfort directly increase pedestrian trip frequency and duration.

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

operation.description: Add street trees with sufficient canopy size along urban streets to increase shade coverage and reduce sky view factor

pathway.mechanism_description: Larger tree canopies intercept direct solar radiation and create shadow zones on street surfaces. The vertical and horizontal extent of tree crowns blocks the view of open sky from ground level, thereby decreasing Sky View Factor (SVF). This reduction in SVF indicates enhanced shade provision, which contributes to thermal comfort improvement in urban street environments

source.citation: Li, X., Ratti, C., & Seiferling, I. (2018). Quantifying the shade provision of street trees in urban landscape: A case study in Boston, USA, using Google Street View. Landscape and Urban Planning, 169, 81–91.

operation.description: Modify the shape and spatial configuration of vegetation elements to create diverse natural forms and patterns in the middleground landscape, enhancing visual complexity and organic composition.

pathway.mechanism_description: Natural vegetation shapes with varied forms increase visual interest and aesthetic appeal through organic diversity. The morphological variation in plant canopies, branching patterns, and growth forms creates visually pleasing compositions that resonate with innate human preferences for natural landscapes, thereby elevating landscape aesthetic preference scores.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.

operation.description: Modify vegetation texture and composition in the middleground to optimize visual complexity and layering as measured by Binocular Vision Index (BVI), creating enhanced depth perception and visual interest.

pathway.mechanism_description: Optimizing vegetation texture in the middleground enhances binocular disparity cues and stereoscopic depth perception. The BVI quantifies this three-dimensional visual quality, which directly correlates with landscape aesthetic preference by providing richer visual information, greater perceived naturalness, and more engaging spatial experience.

source.citation: Li, X., Shang, W.-L., Liu, Q., Liu, X., Lyu, Z., & Ochieng, W. (2024). Towards a sustainable city: Deciphering the determinants of restorative park and spatial patterns. Sustainable Cities and Society, 104, 105292.
